questions.text: What is the most common sequelae of traumatic shoulder dislocation in young adults?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent shoulder dislocation

 

SEQUELAE OF TRAUMATIC SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Recurrent dislocation is most common in shoulder joint, accounting for nearly 50% of all dislocations.
  • Most commonly it is subcoracoid type.
  • Other complications include:
    • Muscle, ligament or tendon rupture
    • Nerve or blood vessel damage around the joint
    • Shoulder instability

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Frozen shoulder. Following dislocation, the shoulder shows some degree of limited motion owing to pain or apprehension for some time, which usually spontaneously recovers. However, some patients experience continuous stiffness after dislocation. This may lead to frozen shoulder if not mobilized early.

 

Option C. Normal shoulder healing and movements. The healing after the shoulder dislocation takes around 12-16 weeks. The movements are started slowly under the rehabilitation process.

 

Option D. Subscapular tendinitis. It is a rare complication of shoulder dislocation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common sequealae of the shoulder dislocation is the recurrence of the shoulder dislocation due to instability of the shoulder joint tissues.

choices.text: For smoothening of edges in amputation surgery
To remove fibrous tissue from non-union site

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is used for:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Used as a bone nibbler

 

BONE NIBBLER

 

  • Bone Nibbler/Bone Rongeurs are like pliers with a heavy, pointed jaw.
  • With their heavy construction, bone nibblers are used for gnawing holes in bones during Orthopedic surgery.
  • The scoop-shaped tip of the rongeur is used for gouging the bone.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. For cutting ribs in thoracic surgery. Rib Shears are surgical instruments used in cardiothoracic surgeries to cut bones, especially ribs. They absorb the shock of the cut and provide an atraumatic experience. 

 

 

Option B. For smoothening of edges in amputation surgery. Putti Bone Rasp is used for orthopedic surgeries that require mild reshaping and handling of bones. It is a double-ended instrument used for debriding and smoothing the bone edges after the amputation surgery.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The image shown in the question is of a bone nibbler which is used to gnaw holes in the bones during the surgery.

questions.text: Salter Harris Type 1 injury passes through which zone?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic zone 

 

SALTER HARRIS CLASSIFICATION 

  • The arrangement of cells of the physis is in layers or zones. 
  • These layers include the reserve, proliferative and hypertrophic zones. 
  • The reserve zone serves as the storage area for lipids, proteoglycans, and glycogen for growth and matrix production later. 
  • The proliferative zone has the highest rate of extracellular matrix production and accounts for the most abundant longitudinal growth. 
  • The hypertrophic zone has three phases: 
    • Maturation allows for preparation for calcification
    • Degenerative further prepare the matrix
    • Provisional calcification zone is where chondrocyte death occurs, allowing for calcium release. 
  • Physeal fractures most commonly occur in the zone of provisional calcification, as it is the weakest in response to shearing stress. 
  • The physis is weaker than ligaments or periosteum in children, causing injury to the growth plate before other structures. 
  • Zones of physis:

 

 

 

  • Salter and Harris described two major types of epiphyseal plates: the pressure epiphysis and the traction epiphysis. 
  • Pressure epiphyses provide longitudinal growth, at the end of long bones, are intra-articular, and bear weight. 
  • Traction epiphyses provide appositional growth, at the origin or insertion of muscles, are extra-articular, and do not bear weight. 
  • Their classification focuses on injuries at pressure epiphyses. 
  • They recognized that physeal fractures consistently occur through the same histologic plane called the zone of provisional calcification. 
  • This zone, located in the zone of hypertrophy, represents a transitional point between calcified and non-calcified extracellular matrix proteins, making it weaker than its surrounding osseous-ligamentous structures, and therefore more susceptible to injury.

 

 

  • In type I injury, there is slip of epiphysis with damage to the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resting zone: It is affected in storage disorders like Gaucher’s disease. 

 

Option B. Proliferative zone: It is affected in growth hormone defects like Larsen’s syndrome. 

 

Option D. Zone of provisional calcification: It is affected in mineralization defects like rickets. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover. 
  • It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur. 
  • Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

questions.text: A small child was playing with her maid where she rotated her by holding from arms. Immediately after, the child started crying. On examination, her forearm was pronated. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pulled elbow

 

  • History of traction on elbow with forearm pronated is classical of pulled elbow.

 

PULLED ELBOW/NURSE MAID’S ELBOW

 

  • It is subluxation of radial head or more accurately subluxation of the annular (orbicular) ligament which slips up over the head of radius into the radio-capitellar joint.

 

 

  • Mechanism of Injury: Traction to elbow.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Maximum incidence in 1-4 years of age group.
    • The child holds the elbow in slight flexion with the forearm pronated.
    • X-rays are normal.
  • Treatment:
    • Reduced by flexing the elbow to 90° and rapidly and firmly rotating the forearm into full supination on outdoor basis without anaesthesia. 
    • Immobilization is not necessary.
    • Supination is a gravity-assisted movement and pulled elbow may be reduced spontaneously by gravity, but this may take time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dislocation of elbow. Elbow Dislocations in the pediatric population usually occur in older children (10-15 years) and can be associated with elbow fractures such as medial epicondyle fractures. Male: female = 3:1. Very rare in younger children < 3 years old. Mechanism of injury is fall on an outstretched hand. Symptoms include painful and swollen elbow, attempts at motion are painful and restricted. On physical examination, the elbow is held in flexion, forearm appears to be shortened from the anterior and posterior view. On palpation, distal humerus creates a fullness within the antecubital fossa. Radiographs shows loss of radiocapitellar and ulnohumeral relationship but maintained radial and ulnar relationship. Treatment is usually closed reduction and brief immobilization for 1-2 weeks. 

 

 

Option C. Fracture head of radius. Radial head fractures are common injuries and may occur in association with dislocation of the elbow. In children, radial neck fractures are more common than radial head fractures. Classically, the head of radius should not be excised in children because it will interfere with the synchronous growth of radius and ulna, producing wrist and elbow deformity. It may lead to proximal radial migration and subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint, weakness of extremity and discomfort in distal radioulnar joint with heavy activities, and may produce cubitus valgus deformity.

 

 

Option D. Fracture coronoid process. Coronoid Fractures are traumatic elbow fractures that are generally pathognomonic for an episode of elbow instability. The patient presents with elbow deformity & swelling, elbow/forearm/wrist pain. On inspection & palpation, there is varus or valgus deformity, ecchymosis & swelling, and diffuse tenderness. The treatment involves brief immobilization, followed by early range of motion. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of traction on elbow with forearm in pronation in a child < 4 years of age is a classical feature of pulled elbow.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with a history of pathological fracture of the neck of femur. On lab investigations, ALP and N-telopeptide levels were raised. The DEXA scan confirmed the diagnosis as osteoporosis. Based on the lab values of osteoporosis, which other values will be raised in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tartrate Resistant Acid Phosphatase

 

In osteoporosis, there is an imbalance between bone resorption (breakdown) and bone formation, with resorption exceeding formation. This leads to bone weakening, which is why the patient has a pathological fracture.

 

The key markers that are elevated in cases of osteoporosis include N & C terminal telopeptides and tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), which are markers of increased bone resorption. In osteoporosis, TRAP levels are elevated, indicating that bone destruction is occurring at a higher rate than formation.

 

Other markers like ALP (alkaline phosphatase) may also be raised, but the specific marker for bone resorption and the correct answer in this case is TRAP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alanine Transaminase: This is a liver enzyme commonly elevated in liver diseases, but it has no direct association with bone metabolism or osteoporosis.

 

Option B. Aspartate Aminotransferase: Like ALT, AST is another liver enzyme, primarily elevated in liver damage and certain heart conditions. It is unrelated to bone resorption or osteoporosis.

 

Option C. Lactate Dehydrogenase: LDH is an enzyme found in many tissues and may be elevated in conditions involving tissue breakdown, but it is not specific to bone resorption or osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis due to increased bone resorption, making it a key marker for this condition.

questions.text: A suspect of sexual assault of 18 years of age claims to be of 16 years. X-rays of which area can confirm the correct age of the suspect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D)  Knee and wrist

 

To determine the accurate age of a person based on bone ossification, certain joints are examined through X-rays. The ossification of specific bones indicates different age groups. The wrist and knee typically ossify by the age of 18, while other joints, such as the elbow, ossify by the age of 16. In this case, the suspect is claiming to be 16 years old, but if X-rays of both the knee and wrist show full ossification, this would confirm that the suspect is actually 18 years old. This is because these areas would not be fully ossified at 16 but would be ossified at 18, matching the age of the suspect.

 

For 18 years of age:

 

 

For 16 years of age:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow and hip: The elbow and hip ossify by the age of 16. If these joints were ossified, it would support the suspect's claim of being 16 years old, which would not be useful in confirming that they are 18.

 

Option B. Elbow and wrist: The elbow ossifies at 16, but the wrist ossifies at 18. This combination would not be conclusive for determining that the suspect is 18 years old.

 

Option C. Knee and elbow: The elbow ossifies at 16, while the knee ossifies at 18. Similar to option B, this combination would be ambiguous and not definitive for confirming that the suspect is 18.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The ossification of the wrist and knee is a reliable indicator of whether an individual is 18 years old, as both these areas ossify by that age.

questions.text: A young patient with RTA sustained an open fracture of femur which was operated and stabilized as shown below. Identify the fixator.(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rail fixator

 

OPEN FRACTURES

 

  • An open fracture occurs when the bone breaks through the skin.
  • These typically result from high-energy injuries and are often associated with significant damage to the surrounding soft tissues and contamination of the wound.
  • Phalanges followed by tibia is the most common site.
  • These injuries are classified into three types according to the Gustillo-Anderson

 

 

  • These injuries require immediate administration of antibiotics and irrigation and debridement of the wound.
  • The goal of the treatment is to achieve fracture healing and to prevent wound infections and osteomyelitis.
  • When the wound is contaminated, an external fixator is initially used.
  • Early coverage of the wound is important to avoid infection.
  • In general, an increase in Gustillo grade is associated with an increase in infection risk.
  • External Fixation:
    • In external fixation the fixation device is external to skin-external fixator or Ilizarov fixator.
    • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis that is an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done. It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV.
    • Open fracture is one of the most common cause for segmental loss of bone.
    • For treating bone gap when Ilizarov ring fixator is used, it achieves union, eradicates infection, corrects deformities, reestablishes limb length and at the same time maintains function.
    • The Rail Fixator is designed for bone transport for reconstructing bone loss following open fracture and sequestrectomy following osteomyelitis. It provides correction through bone transport, compression-distraction and bifocal lengthening. 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. K-nail. Femoral shaft fractures are one of the commonest high energy fractures, and intramedullary nailing is the gold standard management of these fractures. Intramedullary fixation is considered superior to plate fixation because of lower rates of infection, early weight-bearing, and lesser chances of non-union. Unlocked Kuntscher nail (K-nail) should only be used for isthmic femoral shaft fractures. The main drawback of K-nail for use in other types of femoral shaft fracture was lack of rotational stability. Nowadays, interlocking intramedullary nail is used for almost all types of femoral shaft fractures because of better rotational stability.

 

 

Option C. Ilizarov fixator. Ilizarov fixator is an effective treatment modality of open comminuted femur fractures with high union rate, adequate alignment and satisfactory functional outcomes. Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis that is an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done. It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV. For treating bone gap when Ilizarov ring fixator is used, it achieves union, eradicates infection, corrects deformities, reestablishes limb length and at the same time maintains function.

 

 

Option D. Proximal femoral nail. The proximal femoral nail (PFN) is an osteosynthetic implant is used to treat proximal femoral fractures in the trochanter area with a closed intramedullary fixation method. It consists of a funnel-shaped intramedullary nail with slight bending to reflect proximal femoral diaphyseal trochanteric morphology. It has two proximal openings, a larger one distally for a large femoral neck lag screw and a smaller one immediately above for a smaller anti-rotation screw/pin. There are small holes at the distal end of the nail for locking screws.  It can be combined with a wire cerclage with an open reduction for additional stability in complicated subtrochanteric fractures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fixator shown in the image in the question is a Rail Fixator, used to treat open fractures to fill the bone gap.

questions.text: Identify the deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D

 

RICKETS

 

  • In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones.
  • Pathology:
    • Irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis
    • Thin and weak new trabeculae
    • On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped

 

 

  • Causes:
    • Vitamin D disorders: nutritional, secondary, malabsorption, decreased liver (25) hydroxylase activity
    • Calcium deficiency
    • Phosphorus deficiency
    • Renal losses: Fanconi syndrome
    • Tumors associated with rickets: GCT, osteoblastoma, fibrous dysplasia, neurofibromatosis
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis).
    • Indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance)
    • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
    • Looser’s zone in 20% cases

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C. Scurvy is a condition caused by dietary lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), hence is also called hypovitaminosis C. It is characterized by an increased bleeding tendency, impaired collagen synthesis resulting in osteoporosis, and impaired wound healing. It is rarely seen in adults. Young children and elderly are more predisposed to scurvy due to diet or overheating of food. It does not occur before 6 months of age. Patients present with lethargy, malaise, bone pain, bleeding diathesis, and impaired wound healing. Pediatric radiographic features include generalized osteopenia, cortical thinning (pencil-point cortex), periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage, expansion of costochondral junctions (scorbutic rosary), hemarthrosis, Wimberger ring sign (circular, opaque shadow around epiphyseal centers of ossification, due to bleeding).

 

 

Option C. Vitamin A. Hypovitaminosis A results from inadequate intake of vitamin A, fat malabsorption, or liver disorders and produces a variety of epithelial alterations. Radiographic features includes slow bone development, widening of cranial sutures with bulging fontanelles, and skull hyperostosis.

 

Option D. Vitamin E. Hypovitaminosis E is rare. It is usually due to the malabsorption of vitamin E, e.g. cystic fibrosis or pancreatic failure. It manifests as dysfunction of the CNS, characteristically presenting with a tremor and ataxia. Tendon reflexes are often absent. Clinically and radiologically it may be indistinguishable from the neurological sequelae of hypovitaminosis B12, i.e. subacute combined degeneration of the cord (SACD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D deficiency presents as thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis with abnormally wide (splaying), cupping or flaring (Brush-like) appearance; and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

questions.text: A young man, aged 25, arrived with complaints of being unable to bend the distal interphalangeal joint of his 4th and 5th fingers. Additionally, he faced difficulty in gripping a piece of paper between his fingers. Where is the probable location of the injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

  • The given clinical scenario depicts paralysis of medial 2 lumbricals and palmar interossei which are supplied by ulnar nerve.
  • Ulnar nerve lies behind medial epicondyle, marked as C in the given image.
  • Ulnar nerve supplies Flexor carpi ulnaris & medial half of flexor digitorum profundus in forearm and in hand, it gives motor supply to hypothenar muscles, adductor pollicis, all interossei and medial two lumbricals.

 

ULNAR NERVE PALSY

 

  1. High ulnar nerve palsy (Injury proximal to elbow): Paralysis of all muscles supplied ulnar nerve in forearm and hand. Sensory deficit in the skin of hand.
  2. Low ulnar nerve palsy (Injury distal one third of forearm): Sparing of forearm muscles, Paralysis of hand muscles. Sensory deficit in the skin of hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The structure marked as A is the deltoid tuberosity. Injury to this part is rare. Its superficial location places it at a risk of trauma, fracture, and sequestration.

 

Option B. The structure marked as B is the lateral epicondyle. The lateral epicondyle is usually involved in the lateral epicondylitis or tennis elbow i.e., the overuse injury secondary to the eccentric overload of the common extensor tendon at the origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) tendon.

 

Option D. The structure marked as D is the anatomical neck of humerus. Here, the shoulder joint capsule is attached. Injury to this part is highly uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The marked structure C is the medial epicondyle. The Ulnar nerve passes from behind the epicondyle. Injury to the ulnar nerve at this area causes ulnar claw hand i.e., the extension of IP joints of 4th and 5th fingers; along with weakness in grip of the hand.

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. The post-op x-ray is shown below. The fracture will heal by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary healing

 

The x-ray shows a fracture that has been treated with plating. This suggests the fracture is undergoing primary healing, which occurs when there is rigid fixation (such as with plates). In primary healing, no callus formation is seen because the bone edges are closely approximated and there is minimal micromotion. Healing occurs through direct bone formation, and intramembranous ossification can be part of this process. However, the overall mechanism here is primary healing, which is specifically associated with rigid internal fixation like plating.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Creeping substitution: This refers to a bone graft healing mechanism where old bone is replaced by new bone. It does not apply to fracture healing in the context of this case.

 

Option B. Intramembranous ossification: While intramembranous ossification can be involved in primary bone healing, it is not the comprehensive mechanism. The broader term is primary healing, which includes processes like intramembranous ossification but is driven by rigid fixation.

 

Option D. Secondary healing: This involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion at the fracture site, as seen with casting or nailing. This is not applicable in this case, where rigid fixation (plating) is used, leading to primary healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary healing occurs with rigid fixation (such as plating) and involves direct bone formation without callus formation. Secondary healing involves callus formation and occurs when there is micromotion, typically seen with casts or nailing.

questions.text: A 65-year-old post-menopausal female came with persistent back ache, not responding to conservative treatment. She has a history of heavy weight lifting 4 months back with progressively increasing pain that worsens on walking and starts radiating down her legs within 100m range of walking, she however feels no pain on climbing up the stairs. Most probable diagnosis is? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lumbar canal stenosis

 

LUMBAR CANAL STENOSIS

 

  • Lumbar spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spinal canal, compressing the nerves travelling through the lower back into the legs.
  • While it may affect younger patients, due to developmental causes, it is more often a degenerative condition that affects people who are typically age 60 and older.
  • Narrowing of the spinal canal usually occurs slowly, over many years or decades.
  • Degenerative spondylosis is a significant etiology of lumbar spinal stenosis.
  • The discs become less spongy with aging, resulting in loss of disc height, and may cause bulging of the hardened disc into the spinal canal.
  • Bone spurs may also occur and ligaments may thicken.
  • All of these can contribute to narrowing of the central canal and may or may not produce symptoms.
  • Degenerative spondylolisthesis is another cause of lumbar spinal stenosis. When degenerative changes of the spine occur, the pars interarticularis can be fractured, and the resulting instability can lead to forward translation of the vertebra.  Sufficient anterior slippage of one vertebra on the next vertebral segment can narrow the spinal canal, leading to stenosis.
  • When the lateral recess and neural foramen are stenosed, symptoms of lumbar radiculopathy may also present.
  • Classification (anatomic):
    • Central stenosis: caused by hypertrophied ligamentaum flavum anteriorly and bulging disc posteriorly with consequent thecal sac compression
    • Lateral recess stenosis: due to facet joint arthropathy with overgrowth of the superior articular facet and osteophyte formation. This results in compression of the descending nerve roots.
    • Foraminal stenosis: due to loss of disc height, foraminal disc protrusion, or osteophyte formation with resultant compression of the exiting nerve root.
    • Extraforaminal stenosis: due to far lateral disc herniation again with resultant exiting nerve root compression 
  • Symptoms may be due to inflammation, compression of the nerve(s) or both.
  • Such symptoms may include:
    • Pain, weakness or numbness in the legs, calves or buttocks, exacerbated by prolonged ambulation, standing, and with lumbar extension, and is relieved by forward flexion and rest.
    • Neurogenic claudication is an important feature. Symptoms are bilateral, but usually asymmetric. Low back pain, numbness, and tingling are present.
    • Cramping in the calves with walking, requiring frequent short rests to walk a distance
    • Pain radiating into one or both thighs and legs, similar to the lay term “sciatica”
    • In rare cases, loss of motor functioning of the legs, loss of normal bowel or bladder function
    • Pain may improve with bending forward, sitting or lying down.
    • Walking upstairs being easier than walking downstairs, as the back is forward flexed with stairs climbing.
    • If patients present with new-onset bowel or bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia, bilateral lower extremity weakness, and/or increased lower extremity, the patient may have developed cauda equina or conus medullaris syndromes. 
  • Degenerative spondylolisthesis and degenerative scoliosis are two conditions that may be associated with lumbar spinal stenosis.
  • Degenerative spondylolisthesis (slippage of one vertebra over another) is caused by osteoarthritis of the facet joints. Most commonly, it involves the L4 slipping over the L5 vertebra. It is usually treated with the same non-surgical (“conservative”) and surgical methods as lumbar spinal stenosis. 
  • Investigations:
    • MRI of the lumbosacral spine is the modality of choice for lumbar spinal stenosis, and CT myelography is an option when MRI is contraindicated.
    • Anteroposterior spinal canal diameters of less than 10 mm are also frequently used for the diagnosis of lumbar spinal stenosis. 
  • Treatment:
    • Management for lumbar spinal stenosis aims at reducing symptoms and improving functional status. 
    • Conservative treatment is the first-line treatment for this condition. 
    • Conservative treatment options include physical therapy, oral anti-inflammatory medications, and epidural steroid injections.
    • The most frequently performed surgical procedure is a laminectomy (Wide pedicle-to-pedicle decompression). This is usually indicated in cases of ongoing pain despite conservative measures for 3-6 months and where there is progressive neurologic deterioration e.g. motor weakness, bowel and/or bladder dysfunction.
    • Laminectomy with fusion (wide pedicle-to-pedicle decompression with instrumented fusion) is indicated when further stability is required, which is done in patients with concurrent segmental instability e.g. spondylolisthesis (degenerative or isthmic) or degenerative scoliosis.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. Vertebral osteoporotic compression fracture. These are very common fragility fractures of the spine that affect up to 50% of people over 80 years old. The patient complains of pain localized to area of fracture. There is focal tenderness or pain with deep palpation of spinous process. Radiographs will show loss of anterior, middle, or posterior vertebral height by 20% or at least 4mm. Treatment is usually non-operative. If the fracture is less than five days old, calcitonin can be used for four weeks to decrease pain. Bisphosphonates can be given to prevent future risk of fragility fractures. Some patients may benefit from an extension orthosis. Surgical options may include vertebroplasty, kyphoplasty, surgical decompression and stabilization.

 

 

Option B. PIVD. A herniated disc in the spine is a condition during which a nucleus pulposus is displaced from intervertebral space. It is a common cause of back pain. Herniated disc pain often presents with burning sensation, and may radiate into the lower extremity. Furthermore, in more severe cases, there can be associated with weakness or sensation changes. The disc prolapse can be very painful. Within a few weeks, most cases heal. In many instances, it does not cause that patient any pain. They are often seen on MRI of asymptomatic patients. The initial treatment should be conservative, unless a patient has severe neurological compromise. Surgery is usually the last resort. Physical therapy is the key for most patients.

 

 

Option D. Isthmic spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis occurs when there is an anterior translation or “slippage” of one vertebral body relative to its caudal vertebral body. In most cases, symptoms associated with spondylolisthesis are chronic.  The primary symptom of chronic spondylolisthesis is back pain, with or without leg pain. Isthmic spondylolisthesis refers to a defect in the pars interarticularis that results in anterior subluxation over time, most commonly at L5-S1 followed by L4-5. The resulting anterior subluxation can produce back pain, central canal stenosis, and lateral recess or foraminal stenosis. The most common etiology for isthmic spondylolisthesis is instability of unilateral or bilateral pars interarticularis. The most common symptom of presentation is low back pain, which may be mechanical in nature, depressed deep tendon reflexes, positive straight leg signs, and diminished sensations. Isthmic spondylolisthesis with low back pain should initially be managed conservatively. Surgical treatment options consist of decompression of the neural elements alone versus decompression with internal fixation for bony fusion to prevent further subluxation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A back pain that worsens on walking and radiates down the legs within 100m of walking, and that does not occur on climbing up the stairs, is suggestive of lumbar canal stenosis where the pain relieves on forward bending the trunk, as in climbing the stairs.

questions.text: Counter force brace is used for:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tennis elbow

 

TENNIS ELBOW OR LATERAL EPICONDYLITIS

 

  • Any occupation that requires repeated/sustained wrist extension or repeated pinching/grasping can result in lateral epicondylitis; the condition is, therefore, not limited to sports-related (i.e., one-handed tennis back hand) injuries.
  • Classically, this is tendonitis of the extensor carpi radialis brevis (common extensor origin) tendon at the lateral humeral epicondyle, but can affect the extensor carpi radialis longus at the supracondylar line.

 

 

  • It may result in small tears, fibrocartilaginous metaplasia, microscopic calcification and painful vascular reaction in tendon fibers close to lateral epicondyle (degenerative changes with angiofibroblastic proliferation).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Localized tenderness at or just below lateral epicondyle.
    • Pain can be reproduced by passively stretching the extensor radialis brevis. This is done by extending the elbow, pronating the forearm and then passively flexing the wrist or active extension of wrist against resistance can produce pain (Cozen’s test).

 

 

  • Pain with resisted extension (as seen in the Chair test) or with activities such as wrist dorsiflexion or gripping activities is typically reported by the patient.
     

  • Management:
    • Usual treatment includes work modification to minimize contributing activities with the focus on a better anthropomorphic match between the user and their work environment in contrast to a one-size-fits-all design strategy.
    • Acute pain can be treated with anti-inflammatories, cold pack massage over the extensor origin, rest, a wrist extensor strengthening regimen, or use of a counterforce (“tennis elbow”) brace.
    • The proposed mechanism for this brace is the dissipation of the forces away from the injured tissue to the surrounding noninjured area. 
    • This type of brace can be both a rehabilitative and a functional orthosis.

 

 

  • Chronic lateral epicondylitis treatment strategies in the context of employment are more controversial.
     

  • Some common treatments include steroid injection, platelet rich plasma, dry needling/trigger point injections, physical therapy to include isometric and concentric exercises, and stretches.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Wrist drop. For wrist drop due to radial nerve palsy, a dynamic cock-up splint is given.

 

 

Option C. Foot drop. For foot drop, an AFO or ankle-foot orthosis or leaf brace is given.

 

 

Option D. Ankle sprain. For ankle sprain, an adjustable ankle brace is given.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Counter force brace is used for the rehabilitation of tennis elbow.
  • This brace dissipates the forces away from the injured tissue to the surrounding non-injured area.

questions.text: A patient after a roadside trauma presented to the trauma center. He has a severe pain in his left hip and, on examination the hip is exquisitely tender with restricted range of motion. The patient is lying in the posture seen below. Which of the following deformity is seen in the patient? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior dislocation of hip

 

ANTERIOR DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted.

 

 

FABER position of limb after dislocation

 

  • The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head.
  • They are associated with lengthening.
  • It is less common than posterior dislocation
  • It is divided into various types according to the position assumed by the femoral head: 
    • Pubic
    • Obturator
    • Perineal
       
  • Clinical Features:
    • Patient assumes externally rotated, abducted and slightly flexed posture at the affected hip, with restriction of movement.
    • Head of femur is often felt either anteriorly (superior type) or in the groin (inferior type).
       
  • Imaging Findings
    • Dislocation is usually seen on AP view; in a few cases, lateral view may be needed to establish the diagnosis.

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • An anterior dislocation usually can be reduced without surgery by pulling longitudinally on the thigh.
    • If the dislocation cannot be reduced by these maneuvers, open reduction is performed.
       
  • Complication: 
    • Avascular necrosis.
    • Because of their anterior relationship to the hip, the femoral vessels and nerve may be injured, especially with pubic dislocations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior dislocation of hip. The head of the femur is pushed out of the acetabulum posteriorly. It is more common (90%). The injury is sustained by violence directed along the shaft of the femur, with the hip flexed in motor accidents. It is, therefore, also known as dashboard injury.

 

 

The patient presents with a history of severe trauma followed by pain, swelling and deformity (flexion, adduction and internal rotation – FADIR), associated with a shortening of the leg.

 

 

In plain radiograph, the femoral head is out of the acetabulum.

 

 

The thigh is internally rotated so, the lesser trochanter is not seen. Shenton’s line is broken. In most cases, it is possible to reduce the hip by closed manipulation under general anaesthesia. Open reduction may be required in cases where closed reduction fails, if there is intra-articular loose fragment, and if the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight-bearing part of the acetabulum. Complications include injury to the sciatic nerve, avascular necrosis of the femoral head, osteoarthritis, myositis ossificans.

 

Option C. Inferior dislocation of hip. Inferior dislocation of hip or luxatio erecta femoris is the rarest among all types of hip dislocation. It can be caused by a severe trauma to the hip. Most of the reported cases involve the pediatric age group. There are two types of inferior hip dislocation; ischial type and obturator type. In the obturator type, when a force is applied to femur while the hip joint is in abduction and flexion, the femoral head dislocates anteriorly and inferiorly to the obturator foramen. In the ischial type, a force is applied to femur while hip and knee joints are in hyperflexion without abduction or external rotation. The femoral head dislocates inferiorly next to the ischium. The ischial type is more common than the obturator type.

 

 

Option D. Central dislocation of hip. A central dislocation involves the femoral head being forced downward. Acetabular fractures with central hip dislocation result from direct axial loading through the greater trochanter in abduction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Restricted hip range of motion with FABER deformity of the hip is suggestive of anterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with lesion in tibial diaphysis. Histopathological examination is shown in below given image. On IHC, it was MIC-2 positive and synaptophysin positive cells. Most likely diagnosis will be: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ewing sarcoma

 

EWING SARCOMA

 

  • Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. 

  • Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life.

  • Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. 

  • Diagnosis:

    • Laboratory studies may reveal an increased white blood cell count, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and an elevated C-reactive protein.

    • A needle aspirate may grossly resemble pus.

    • Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. 

 

 

  • The image provided in the question shows a tumor composed of numerous small, relatively uniform, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm. This is the classic "small round blue cell tumor" appearance, which is typical of Ewing sarcoma.

 

  • Markers/Cytogenetics:

  • Ewing's sarcoma is part of a family of peripheral neuroectodermal tumors (PNET) that share a common cytogenetic translocation of chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11:22).

  • MIC2 (CD99) is a specific marker for Ewing's sarcoma and is expressed on short-arm of chromosome x and y. This is a highly characteristic and almost universally positive marker for Ewing sarcoma. It is often used as the primary diagnostic marker.

  • Synaptophysin is more commonly associated with neuroendocrine tumors, but it can be focally positive in some Ewing sarcomas, reflecting its neuroectodermal origin. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma (NB) is the most frequently-occurring extracranial childhood tumor. It is classified as an embryonal neuroendocrine tumor, originating from neural crest progenitor cells. Hence, it can occur anywhere along the sympathetic nervous system, including the superior cervical, paraspinal, and celiac ganglia; the majority arise in the adrenal glands. The most important biological marker is MYCN. Patients with the MYCN gene tend to have rapid progression of cancer and poor outcomes. Other biological markers linked to poor prognosis include lack of expression of glycoprotein CD 44, elevated levels of telomerase RNA, elevated levels of LDH, serum ferritin, and serum neuron-specific enolase. 90% patients have elevations in vanillyl mandelic acid and homovanillic acid in the urine. Histopathology reveal small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes (in 10-15% cases), with clustering of cells in the connective tissue. 

 

 

Small, round, blue cells known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma. Onset can occur at any age; however, primary high-grade osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus. Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance. Histologically, osteoid production from the tumor cells is seen, presenting as calcification. 

 

 

Codman’s triangle 

 

Option D. Osteoclastoma. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of the giant cells, a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumors from other tumors that may contain many giant cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.

questions.text: Match the Eponym with their fractures.(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-e

 

  • The correct description of the given fractures are:

 

 

COMMON FRACTURE EPONYMS

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

1. Pilon’s fracture: It is the intra-articular comminuted fracture of the distal tibia. It is also known as Plafond fracture, Tibia Plafond fracture, Distal Tibial Explosion fracture. The high energy axial compression force if the tibia acts as a pestle, driving vertically into the talus.

 

 

2. Runner’s fracture: It is the fracture of lower end of the fibula. They are usually the stress fracture, commonly seen in runners.

 

 

3. Cotton’s fracture: It is the trimalleolar fracture in the ankle i.e., there is involvement of medial and lateral malleoli, and posterior aspect of the tibial plafond (also called as posterior malleolus). This is a more unstable fracture and may be associated with ligamentous injury.

 

 

4. Chauffer’s fracture: It is an intra-articular oblique fracture of the styloid process of the radius. It is sustained from a direct trauma like a blow to the back of the wrist or from forced dorsiflexion and abduction of the wrist.

choices.text: Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

questions.text: Identify the condition and the instrument:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

 

RULE OF IMMOBILISATION

 

  • Immobilise one joint above and 1 joint below the main target
  • Femur fracture: Fixation at hip joint and knee joint
  • Tibia fracture: Fixation at knee joint and ankle joint
  • Periarticular Knee fracture: Fixation at hip joint and ankle joint
  • Peri- and intra-articular fractures about the knee are frequently managed with joint-spanning external fixation before definitive treatment.
  • With a systematic approach, a near-anatomic reduction with respect to length, alignment, and rotation can be obtained.

 

KNEE SPANNING EXTERNAL FIXATOR

 

  • A joint-bridging external fixator is fixed to the femur and the tibia while the fracture zone is left virtually untouched (it is bridged).
  • Provisional reduction is achieved with distraction.
  • When external fixation is used to bridge the knee joint, it is always only for temporary fixation. Prolonged immobilization will lead to difficulties with knee mobility.
  • It is rapidly applied without need for intraoperative x-rays and can be adjusted later.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Tibia fracture, Ilizarov fixator. The most stable external fixation for distal tibial fractures is usually composed by:

 

  • One fully circular ring with tensioned wires attached to the distal tibial articular segment
  • Two proximal fully circular rings to provide stable anchorage for the distal ring
  • An extension for the foot and ankle, and particularly for intraarticular fractures
  • 3-4 connecting rods between each ring

 

The proximal rings can be anchored with Schanz screws or tensioned wires. Wires are usually used in cancellous bone. Wires attached to a circular ring are typically tensioned at 100 to 130 kg-force.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

A spanning external fixator is used for stabilization of open and closed fractures, mainly intraarticular fractures of the lower extremity, around the knee and ankle joints.

choices.text: Bar and boot plaster

questions.text: An 80-year-old patient suffers with Intracapsular femoral neck fracture. What would be the most appropriate management option for her management?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemiarthroplasty

 

INTRACAPSULAR FEMORAL NECK FRACTURE

 

  • Intracapsular femoral neck fractures (FNFs) account for approximately 50% of all hip fractures.
  • Intracapsular fractures demonstrate limited healing potential due to the absence of the periosteal layer, so the fracture is only immersed in the surrounding synovial fluid. 
  • These injuries occur secondary to low-energy falls in older individuals and higher-energy traumatic mechanisms in younger patients. 
  • However, most of these fractures occur in older people with underlying osteoporosis.
  • Displaced intracapsular femoral neck fractures in older people are typically managed with hip reconstruction procedures – the femoral head and neck are replaced with a reconstruction prosthesis.
  • These procedures include hip hemiarthroplasty or total hip arthroplasty (THA).
  • Non-displaced fractures may be managed with fixation using cannulated screw fixation.
  • Hemiarthroplasty, or femoral head replacement, is recommended for displaced intracapsular FNFs, especially in older patients with low activity levels.
  • THA is preferred for patients with intact ambulatory function or evidence of hip pain and degenerative arthritis.
  • Girdlestone resection arthroplasty (GRA) may be an option for patients who are unsuitable for hemiarthroplasty due to conditions like systemic infections or severe neurological impairment.
  • Hemiarthroplasty and THA are contraindicated in patients with an active hip infection.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Russell’s traction: This is a non-surgical method used for younger patients with femoral neck fracture with good bone quality. It might not be ideal for an 80-year-old due to potential complications from prolonged immobilization.

 

Option B. Bar and boot plaster: This non-surgical method also has limitations for elderly patients due to healing complications.

 

Option C. Intramedullary nailing: This surgical procedure uses nails to fix the fracture. While it can be an option, it might be risky for an 80-year-old's bone quality.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hemiarthroplasty is a surgical procedure where the damaged femoral head is replaced with an artificial joint, preserving the patient's own socket.
  • This offers a good balance between pain relief, mobility, and surgical complexity for elderly patients with this type of fracture.
  • The most appropriate management option for an 80-year-old patient with an intracapsular femoral neck fracture is Hemiarthroplasty.

choices.text: Bar and boot plaster

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient suffers with extracapsular femoral neck fracture. What would be the most appropriate management option for her management?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intramedullary nailing

 

INTRAMEDULLARY NAILING

 

  • Intramedullary Nailing is a surgical technique used to stabilize fractures by inserting a metal rod (nail) into the medullary canal of the bone.
  • Mechanism: The nail is inserted into the central canal of the femur and fixed with screws at the ends to stabilize the fracture.

 

 

  • It is generally used for femoral shaft fractures but can be applied to extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly.
  • Indications: Intramedullary nailing is effective for stabilizing long bone fractures and can be used for femoral neck fractures if the fracture pattern and bone quality are suitable.
  • Complications: There is a risk of complications including infection, nonunion, and poor functional outcomes if not done properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Russell’s Traction: Russell’s Traction is a type of skeletal traction used to align and stabilize fractures, particularly in the lower extremities. This traction method involves applying a pulling force to the limb through a system of pulleys and weights. It can help in aligning fractured bones and reducing pain by immobilizing the affected limb. For elderly patients with extracapsular femoral neck fractures, Russell’s traction is less preferred due to delayed recovery as the traction does not allow early weight-bearing or mobility, which is crucial for elderly patients to prevent complications like pressure sores and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The immobilization provided by traction alone might not adequately stabilize the fracture, leading to a higher risk of nonunion or malunion. Prolonged use of traction can lead to muscle atrophy and joint stiffness.

 

 

Option B. Bar and Boot Plaster: Bar and Boot Plaster is a type of external immobilization used for fractures, particularly in the lower limb. This involves applying a plaster cast to immobilize the fractured limb, often including a bar and boot to provide additional support and alignment. It is used for fractures where conservative management is appropriate, particularly in pediatric or less complex cases. For extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients, this method is generally not preferred due to inadequate stabilization. Prolonged immobilization can lead to complications such as muscle atrophy, joint stiffness, and pressure sores, especially in elderly patients who are already at high risk for these issues.

 

 

Option D. Hemiarthroplasty: Hemiarthroplasty involves replacing the damaged femoral head with a prosthetic component while leaving the acetabulum intact. It is often used to address both the fracture and any pre-existing joint degeneration. Hemiarthroplasty is often preferred for intracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients due to immediate stability provided to the hip joint and allowance for earlier weight-bearing and mobility, which is crucial for elderly patients to reduce the risk of complications from prolonged immobility. The prosthesis can alleviate pain and improve functional outcomes compared to conservative management methods. The procedure has risks such as dislocation, infection, and prosthesis failure, but it generally provides better outcomes in terms of mobility and quality of life for elderly patients compared to non-surgical methods.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramedullary nailing, while useful for certain types of fractures, is generally the first choice for extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients due to the risks and potential complications associated with the procedure.
  • Cephalomedullary nailing is done in such cases.

questions.text: While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hoover’s sign

 

HOOVER TEST:

 

  • Hoover’s sign is a maneuver to separate organic from non-organic paresis of Leg.
  • Principle: Synergistic Contraction.
  • Involuntary extension of normal leg occurs with flexion of contralateral limb against resistance.
  • Test Positioning:
    • The subject relaxes in a supine position on the table while the examiner places both of the subject’s heels into their palm.
  • Action:
    • The subject is asked to perform a unilateral straight leg raise.
  • Positive Finding:
    • The inability to lift the leg may reflect a neuromuscular weakness.
    • A positive finding is also noted when the examiner does not feel increased pressure in the palm that underlies the resting leg.
    • Organic Cause: Flexion of paralyzed limb → heel of normal limb pushes the examiner’s hand.
    • Functional Weakness: Heel does not pushdown, i.e. the effort is not being transmitted.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waddell’s test. Tests of malingering. Each test counts as +1 if +ve, 0 if –ve. This includes Superficial skin tenderness to light pinch over wide area of lumbar spine; Deep tenderness over wide area, often extending to thoracic spine, sacrum, and/or pelvis; Low back pain on axial loading of spine in standing; SLR test positive in supine, but not when seated with knee extended to test Babinski reflex; Abnormal or inconsistent neurological (motor and/or sensory) patterns; Overreaction. If 3+ points or more are there, investigate for non-organic cause.

 

Option B. O’ Donoghue’s test. Structures affected: Cervical spinal muscles and/or cervical spinal ligaments. The cervical spine of a seated patient is passively flexed, extended, laterally flexed to both sides, and rotated in both directions against patient resistance. Pain precipitated by such isometric contraction indicates cervical strain. The test is then repeated without patient resistance. Pain precipitated by passive unrestricted motion signifies cervical sprain.

 

 

O’Donoghue’s Maneuver for Knee Joint: This maneuver can be used to diagnose meniscal pathologies in the knee. With the patient in prone, the examiner flexes the knee to 90° and then rotates the tibia internally and externally twice, then fully extends the knee and repeat the rotations. Increased pain during rotation in either or both knee positions indicates a meniscal tear or joint capsule irritation. With a valgus force to a flexed and laterally rotated knee, the medial meniscus, medial collateral ligament (MCL), and ACL all may be injured, representing the O'Donoghue triad.

 

Option D. McMurray test. This test indicates tears of the middle or posterior horn of the meniscus. With the patient supine and the hip and knee fully flexed, apply a valgus force and externally rotate the tibia while extending the knee. An audible or palpable pop or snap indicates a medial meniscal tear. Lesions of the lateral meniscus are tested by applying a varus force and internally rotating the tibia during knee extension. The snap is produced as the torn fragment rides over the femoral condyle during extension. A snap in extreme flexion is indicative of a posterior horn tear; a click at 90° of flexion indicates a lesion in the middle section of the meniscus. Only 57% of meniscal root tears result in a positive McMurray test. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as Hoover’s sign.

questions.text: Which part of 2nd metatarsal is involved in the march fracture?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neck

 

MARCH FRACTURE

 

  • March fracture is a stress fatigue fracture of second metatarsal neck > 3rd metatarsal neck.
  • The second metatarsal is more prone to injury due to its limited motion from strong ligamentous attachment to the first and second cuneiforms and length compared to the other foot metatarsals.
  • They result from a sudden increase in the intensity, duration, and frequency of activity without sufficient rest.
  • The repetitive impact on the metatarsals with weight-bearing exercises causes microfractures, which consolidate into stress fractures and are not the result of a single traumatic event.

 

 

  • Common Fracture Eponyms:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The march fracture involves the neck of the 2nd metatarsal followed by 3rd metatarsal.
  • It is a stress fracture of the metatarsal.

questions.text: Identify the implant shown in the image used for treatment of proximal femoral fracture. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dynamic hip screw

 

The image shows an implant used for the treatment of proximal femoral fractures, specifically intertrochanteric fractures. The implant depicted is a Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS), which is composed of two main components: a large screw (commonly referred to as a Richard screw) and a plate with a barrel. The screw slides within the barrel as the bone heals, allowing controlled movement and promoting bone union.

 

The DHS has been the gold standard for treating intertrochanteric fractures, especially extracapsular femoral neck fractures. It works by providing stability while allowing dynamic compression at the fracture site, which helps in bone healing. However, with advancements in medical technology, cephalomedullary nails (such as the proximal femoral nail) have largely replaced the DHS for such fractures in recent times.

 

Two types of proximal femoral fractures:

 

  1. Fracture of the neck of femur (intra-capsular):
    • Less than 65 years of age: Perform closed reduction (do not open) and fix with cannulated cancellous screw fixation (fixation with screws).
    • More than or equal to 65 years of age: Perform hemiarthroplasty (replace half the joint).
    • Any age with joint damage: Perform total hip replacement (for hip joint damage).
    • Neck of femur fracture is also referred to as the unsolved fracture.
  2. Intertrochanteric fractures:
    • Treatment options include the dynamic hip screw or proximal femoral fracture treatment.
    • Modern treatment involves placing nails:
      • Cephalomedullary or proximal femoral nail: A nail is placed inside the femur, with a screw into the head of the femur.
    • Fractures lower down: Treated with interlock nailing.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dynamic condylar plate: The dynamic condylar plate is primarily used for distal femoral fractures, not proximal femoral fractures like intertrochanteric fractures. It does not have the screw-barrel mechanism that is specific to the dynamic hip screw.

 

Option C. Dynamic trochanteric plate: While similar-sounding, the dynamic trochanteric plate is not commonly used for intertrochanteric fractures. The DHS is more specifically designed for dynamic compression in such cases.

 

Option D. Limited contact condylar plate: This plate is generally used for fractures that require minimal disturbance of the periosteum, but it is not typically used for intertrochanteric fractures, which require dynamic fixation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS) is a two-part implant, featuring a screw and a plate, and is used to treat intertrochanteric fractures of the proximal femur.

questions.text: Book test is for: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ulnar nerve

 

TESTS FOR ULNAR NERVE PALSY

 

  • Froment sign/book test: Hyperflexion of the thumb IP joint while attempting to pinch. This indicates a substitution of flexor pollicis longus (innervated by median nerve) for adductor pollicis (innervated by ulnar nerve).

 

 

  • Jeanne sign: Reciprocal hyperextension of the thumb MCP joint indicating substitution of flexor pollicis longus (FPL) for adductor pollicis.

 

 

  • Wartenburg sign: Abduction of the small finger at MCP joint indicating deficient palmar intrinsic muscle (innervated by ulnar nerve) with abduction from extensor digiti minimi (innervated by the radial nerve).

 

 

  • Duchenne sign: Clawing of the ring and small fingers, hyperextension of MCP joints, and flexion of PIP joints indicating deficient interosseous and lumbrical muscles of the ring and small fingers.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve. Special tests for median nerve injury are:

 

  • Pen Test:
    • Test: Patient keeps his/her hand flat on the table and at the same time, examiner brings a pen above the thumb.
    • Interpretation: Patient tries to touch the pen by abduction the thumb and examiner feels the tendon of abductor pollicis brevis (APB) at the wrist. Patient fails to touch in APB paralysis and examiner will not be able to palpate the tendon.
    • Note: Median nerve invariably and exclusively supply APB.

 

 

  • Pointing Index Sign/Ochsner’s Clasping/Benediction Test:
    • Test: Patient clasps his both hand together.
    • Interpretation: The index finger fails to flex in median nerve injury and it points outward as pointing index.
    • Note: It occur in high median nerve palsy where flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus gets involved.

 

 

A. Pointing index; B. Benediction test

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness. Depending on injury severity there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Option D. Radial nerve. Special tests for radial nerve palsy are:

 

  • Wrist drop test:
    • The patient is asked to extend wrist with the elbow flexed 90°.
    • In radial nerve palsy affecting the wrist extensors, the patient will be unable to extend the wrist. The hand will hang down in a deformity known as a “wrist drop“.

 

 

a. Normal; b. Wrist drop

 

  • In a second stage of the test, the patient is asked to abduct the thumb.
  • In radial nerve palsy, the patient will be unable to abduct the thumb because of the paralysis of the abductor pollicis longus muscle and, to a lesser extent, the extensor pollicis brevis muscle.

 

 

a. Thumb abduction; b. Paralysis

 

  • Thumb extension test:
    • The examiner grasps the patient’s wrist with one hand and presses the thumb into adduction with the other hand.
    • Then the patient is asked to extend or abduct both the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints of the thumb.
    • Where this nerve is damaged, thumb extension will be weakened or impossible as a result of paralysis of the extensor pollicis longus and brevis.

 

 

a. Starting position; b. Normal; c. Weak thumb extension

 

  • Supination test:
    • Supination Test evaluates compression neuropathy of the deep branch of the radial nerve.
    • The patient is seated, holding the elbow slightly flexed and the forearm pronated.
    • The elbow is held alongside the trunk to minimize motion in the shoulder.
    • The patient is then asked to supinate forearm, at first normally and then against the examiner’s resistance.
    • Weakness or loss of supination of the forearm is a sign of paresis of the supinator muscle, which is supplied by the deep branch of the radial nerve.

 

 

a. Starting position; b. Normal supination; c. Supination against resistance

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Book test is done for ulnar nerve palsy where there is hyperflexion of the thumb IP joint while attempting to pinch, indicating a substitution of flexor pollicis longus (innervated by median nerve) for adductor pollicis (innervated by ulnar nerve).

questions.text:
Which of the following statement/s is/are true regarding open fracture?(INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Compartment syndrome is rare.
  2. Immediate debridement should be done.
  3. Tibia is the most common long bone involved.
  4. Multiple fractures are uncommon.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) I, II & III are correct

 

I. Compartment syndrome is rare: True

 

  • In open fractures, the fascia may be disrupted, which reduces the risk of rising compartment pressure.

  • However, compartment syndrome can still occur, especially in high-energy injuries, so it is not impossible, but it is less common compared to closed fractures.

 

II. Immediate debridement should be done: True

 

  • Early and thorough surgical debridement is the cornerstone of open fracture management to reduce infection risk.

  • Ideally performed within 6–8 hours, though recent evidence suggests that a short delay may not significantly change infection rates if antibiotics are given promptly.

 

III. Tibia is the most common long bone involved: True

 

  • The tibia is the most commonly involved long bone in open fractures due to its subcutaneous location (minimal soft tissue coverage).

  • Therefore, it’s more vulnerable to open injuries, especially in road traffic accidents.

 

IV. Multiple fractures are uncommon: False

  • Multiple fractures are actually common, particularly in high-energy trauma like road traffic accidents, falls from height, or blast injuries.

  • Open fractures often occur as part of polytrauma.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In open fracture, compartment syndrome is a rare entity as the fracture communicates with the surrounding atmosphere, preventing an increase in the compartment pressure.
  • These fractures need immediate irrigation with antibiotics and debridement of the wound.
  • Tibia is the most common site for open fractures after phalanges.

questions.text: Diagnose the condition shown in the following image.  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Chronic Osteomyelitis is a long-standing infection of the bone that typically results from bacteria, most commonly staphylococcus aureus.
  • It is characterized by persistent pain, swelling, warmth, and redness over the affected area.
  • The infection often leads to chronic discharge from a sinus tract or wound, and systemic symptoms may be less pronounced compared to acute infections.
  • On radiographs or MRI, chronic osteomyelitis may present as:
    • Bone Destruction: There can be areas of bone destruction or loss with possible formation of sequestra (dead bone) and involucrum (new bone formation surrounding the dead bone).
    • Sinus Tracts: Imaging may show draining sinus tracts or soft tissue swelling.
    • Cortical Erosion: There might be cortical erosion or irregularity.

 

 

  • Histopathology: Chronic osteomyelitis is characterized by the presence of chronic inflammatory cells, granulation tissue, and sometimes necrotic bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing’s Sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor typically found in children and young adults. It is one of the small round blue cell tumors. Patients usually present with localized pain, swelling, and possibly systemic symptoms like fever. The tumor often affects long bones or the pelvis.  On radiographs or MRI, Ewing’s sarcoma can present as a permeative lesion with ill-defined margins, an onion skin periosteal reaction. It is typically associated with an extensive soft tissue mass, an osteolytic lesion with or without calcifications. Histopathologically, it is characterized by small round blue cells with a characteristic "small round cell" appearance and is often confirmed with immunohistochemical staining and cytogenetic analysis (e.g., EWS-FLI1 fusion gene).

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that primarily affects adolescents and young adults. It is characterized by pain, swelling, and occasionally a palpable mass. It is commonly located around the knee or the metaphysis of long bones. On radiographs or MRI, osteosarcoma may present as mixed osteolytic and osteoblastic (sclerotic) lesions, formation of new bone perpendicular to the cortex due to the aggressive nature of the tumor lifting the periosteum, called as Codman’s triangle, and a soft tissue mass. Histopathologically, it shows pleomorphic osteoblasts producing malignant osteoid or bone matrix. Diagnosis is confirmed through biopsy and histological examination.

 

Codman’s triangle

 

Option D. Acute Osteomyelitis: Acute Osteomyelitis is a recent infection of the bone, usually caused by bacteria. Symptoms include rapid onset of severe pain, swelling, redness, and warmth over the affected area, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever and malaise. On radiographs or MRI, acute osteomyelitis may not show significant bone changes initially, but can later show bone marrow edema and possible periosteal reaction. As the condition progresses, there may be evidence of bone destruction, sequestra formation, or an abscess. Histopathologically, it is typically characterized by acute inflammatory changes with neutrophils and potentially abscess formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic Osteomyelitis is characterized by long-standing infection, typically with a chronic clinical course and imaging findings that reflect bone destruction and chronic inflammation.
  • The given image in the question shows sequestrum and involucrum in the lower end of femur, which are typically characteristic of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: Which muscle is affected if the patient is unable to make an "OK" sign? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flexor pollicis longus

 

The inability to make an "OK" sign is typically caused by a lesion of the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. This nerve innervates three muscles, including the flexor pollicis longus (FPL), which is responsible for flexing the thumb. When the FPL is affected, the patient cannot flex the distal phalanx of the thumb, resulting in an inability to form the "OK" sign with their hand. The term "Kiloh-Nevin sign" is used to describe this clinical finding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor pollicis brevis: This muscle abducts the thumb and is innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve. It does not contribute to flexing the thumb for the "OK" sign.

 

Option C. Lumbricals: These muscles flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints. They are not involved in making the "OK" sign.

 

Option D. Opponens pollicis: This muscle is involved in opposition of the thumb, allowing the thumb to touch the fingers, but it does not contribute directly to the flexion of the thumb required for the "OK" sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexor pollicis longus is essential for making the "OK" sign, and its impairment is a key clinical feature of anterior interosseous nerve damage.

questions.text: Glucosamine supplementation is given in:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arthritis

 

TREATMENT OF OSTEOARTHRITIS

 

  • Maintain movement and muscle strength by physiotherapy and graded muscle exercise.
  • Protects the joint from overload by giving rest and weight reduction.
  • Correction of deformities if present.
  • Thermal modalities, analgesic medication, wedged insoles, orthosis and arthroscopic debridement and lavage.
  • Progressive joint destruction require joint replacement in elderly and HTO in young.
  • Stages of osteoarthritis:

 

 

  • Classification system and stage-wise management for osteoarthritis (OA) knee:
    • Initial treatment is always conservative (exercise and glucosamine are preferred).
    • Clinical picture is more significant than radiology or X-ray changes.
    • If activities of daily living are affected, surgery is advised.
    • Surgery for young patients is high tibial osteotomy (HTO) (if not contraindicated), if contraindicated, total knee replacement (TKR) is performed.
    • Surgery for elderly (> 65 years) is TKR.
    • Usually for stage 2 onwards in elderly, TKR is finally carried out.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glucosamine supplementations are given in the treatment of osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male complained of gradual swelling around the wrist for 3 months. X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giant cell tumor

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is the bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells – A feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.
       
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance, without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis
       
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The x-ray image shown in the question is diagnostic of Giant cell tumor of the distal end of radius.
  • Tumor of distal end radius is GCT, until proved otherwise.

choices.text: Anterior dislocation of hip
Posterior dislocation of hip
Inter-trochanteric fracture of femur
Fracture neck of femur

questions.text: A patient fell down riding a bicycle. He started having pain around hip. There was shortening of limb, and the attitude of limb was Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior dislocation of hip

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • It is more common (90%)
  • Mechanism of injury:
    • Dashboard injury: occur with axial load applied on a flexed knee placed in adduction - seen as one sits in the front seat of the car.
       
  • The typical attitude of the lower limb would be a flexion, adduction and internal rotation (FADIR).

 

 

  • Complications: AVN of femoral head, sciatic nerve injury, associated fractures of femoral head and acetabulum and also associated knee injuries.
  • Imaging Findings:
    • Dislocation is usually seen on AP view; in a few cases, lateral view may be needed to establish the diagnosis.

 

 

  • CT scan is the best investigation to judge dislocation.
     
  • Treatment:
    • More the deformity is a sign that probably there is no associated fracture of acetabulum or femoral head/neck. These cases can undergo closed reduction under some sedation.
    • Reduction under general anesthesia (GA).

 

Other options:
