Option A. Anterior Dislocation of Hip. It is less common than posterior dislocation. It is of 2 types. Type I: Pubic (femoral head lies superiorly) and Type II: Obturator (femoral head lies inferiorly). Patient assumes externally rotated, abducted and slightly flexed posture (FABER) at the affected hip, with restriction of movement. Head of femur is often felt either anteriorly (superior type) or in the groin (inferior type). Dislocation is usually seen on AP view. Treatment is reduction under general anesthesia (GA).

 

 

 

Option C. Inter-trochanteric fracture of femur. The patients suffering from intertrochanteric femoral fractures are mainly of elder age group (> 60 years of age) with poor health condition & comorbidities. It is seen more commonly in males. The patient presents with severe pain, swelling & ecchymosis. There is tenderness present over the greater trochanter. The hip is externally rotated to > 45° (lateral border of foot touches the couch). There is > 1 inch of shortening in the affected limb. Broadening of greater trochanter is seen. The patient is unable to walk and SLR is also not possible.

 

 

Option D. Fracture neck of femur. Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. The junctional location makes the femoral neck prone to fracture. They are associated with low energy falls in the elderly. In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. Risk factors include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density. Displaced fractures put the blood supply at risk, usually tearing the ascending cervical branches. This may compromise the healing of the fracture, inevitably causing non-union or osteonecrosis. Non-operative management for these fractures is rarely the treatment course. Young patients with femoral neck fractures will require treatment with emergent open reduction internal fixation. Non-displaced fractures are treated typically with percutaneous cannulated screws or a sliding hip screw. With displaced fractures in less active elderly patients, the treatment is given by hemiarthroplasty and with more active individuals, total hip arthroplasty is done.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The limb position of flexion, adduction and internal rotation (FADIR) is specific of posterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with knee pain following a fall from the stairs. The physical and radiological evaluation revealed injury to the marked structure. Identify the structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tibial tuberosity

 

In this case, the injury is localized to the tibial tuberosity, a prominent bony projection on the anterior aspect of the tibia. The tibial tuberosity serves as the attachment point for the patellar ligament. Injuries to this region, especially in young, active individuals (often seen in adolescents), can be associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease, which is an osteochondritis of the tibial tuberosity. This condition is common in children and adolescents undergoing growth spurts and is characterized by knee pain, swelling, and tenderness at the tibial tuberosity following physical activity or trauma, such as a fall from stairs.

 

The patient in this question, a 10-year-old with knee pain after a fall, shows signs consistent with Osgood-Schlatter disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medial tubercle: The medial tubercle refers to the medial part of the tibial plateau and is not directly related to the symptoms or the location of the injury in this case.

 

Option C. Gerdy's tubercle: Gerdy's tubercle is the insertion site for the iliotibial band on the lateral side of the tibia. The injury in the image and description does not involve Gerdy's tubercle, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Anterior intercondylar area: This area is located between the condyles of the tibia and is the site of cruciate ligament attachments. However, this is not the structure marked or injured in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tibial tuberosity is the site of attachment for the patellar ligament, and injuries to this region, particularly in young individuals, can result in conditions such as Osgood-Schlatter disease, characterized by pain at the site, especially following physical activity or trauma.

choices.text: Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints
Post-traumatic dystrophy with complex regional pain syndrome

questions.text: A woman presents with pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand. There were associated complaints of morning stiffness with problem in squatting. The swelling spared the DIP joints. The image of the patient’s hands is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rheumatoid arthritis

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • Older women (> 60 year) are 6 times more commonly involved than younger one.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis: Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
      • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
    1. Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles, MTP joint
    2. Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint, upper cervical spine
    3. Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
      • Usually, DIP is not involved. It is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops.
      • Lumbar spine is spared.
      • Others: The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children. Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
  • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
  • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis in patients of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

 

  • Radiological Features:
    • Reduced joint space
    • Erosion of articular margins
    • Subchondral cysts
    • Juxta-articular rarefaction
    • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
    • Deformities of the hand and fingers

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heberden's nodes on pre-existing osteoarthritis. Heberden’s nad Bouchard’s nodes are firm swellings over the superolateral and dorsal aspects of DIP and PIP joints respectively. Lateral view of the x-ray of the hand reveals large exostoses arising from the proximal ends of the distal phalanges in the attachment of extensor and flexor tendons. They may begin as small, round, fluctuant, tender mass, a little to one side of the dorsum of the joint.

 

 

 

Option C. Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints. Tenosynovitis is quite common, but it is generally not a striking or isolated clinical complaint. The most common sites are the extensor tendon sheaths on the dorsum of the hand, the extensor sheaths over the dorsum of the foot, and those of the posterior tibial tendon and the peroneus longus and brevis tendons. If tenosynovitis is very prominent, Blau syndrome should be considered. Triggering or loss of extension of the fingers may result from a stenosing synovitis of the flexor tendon sheaths.

 

 

Option D. Post-traumatic dystrophy with complex regional pain syndrome. CRPS is characterized by a chronic neurological disorder involving upper or lower limbs after any type of injury or surgery. In some cases, it occurs spontaneously. Sensory and autonomic disturbances are the main features of this syndrome (allodynia or hyperalgesia, edema, changes in skin blood flow or abnormal sudomotor activity) and are disproportionate to the starting event. The underlying mechanism is still unknown. Multiple mechanisms considered to play a role in the generation and maintenance of CRPS includes biofeedback from autonomic nervous system, alterations of central nervous system, neurogenic inflammation and immunological mechanisms. There is no specific diagnostic test for CRPS. History, clinical examination, symptoms and signs of the patient are the main aspects to be considered for a correct diagnosis. CRPS does not have a pathognomonic sign. The key symptom is prolonged pain that may be constant and disproportionate to the initial injury. The characteristics of the pain are continuous, spontaneous or episodic. Patients frequently described this symptom as burning. The distal part of the limb is the most common area and the typical clinical manifestations are red skin, pain, and swelling. Symptoms may change over time and vary from patient to patient. Over time the injured limb can became pale, cold and in addition muscle spasm and tightening can appear. This condition is often irreversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image and the symptoms in a female of pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand, morning stiffness with problem in squatting is clinical for Rheumatoid Arthritis.

questions.text: Which action will be impacted in PIN Palsy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extension of fingers

 

  • PIN palsy can occur from repetitive pronation-supination movements, fracture/dislocation (e.g., monteggia fracture, radial head fracture, etc.), ganglion, rheumatoid synovitis of radiocapitellar joint.
  • PIN is a branch of the radial nerve that provides motor innervation to the extensor compartment of the forearm. 
  • Course:
    • Passes between the two heads of origin of the supinator muscle 
    • Direct contact with the radial neck 
    • Passes over abductor pollicis longus muscle origin to reach interosseous membrane
    • Transverses along the posterior interosseous membrane
  • Innervation:
    • Common extensors: ECRB, Extensor digitorum communis, Extensor digiti minimi, Extensor carpi ulnaris 
    • Deep extensors: Supinator, Abductor pollicis longus, Extensor pollicus brevis, Extensor pollicus longus 
  • The symptoms of PIN palsy are often insidious in onset, usually goes undiagnosed.
  • The patient complaints of pain in the forearm and wrist, and weakness of finger, wrist and thumb movements 
  • On examination, there is forearm extensor compartment muscle atrophy, weakness of finger metacarpal extension, wrist extension, and an inability to extend wrist in ulnar deviation. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supination of forearm: This movement is facilitated by the supinator, biceps brachii and brachioradialis muscles. The supinator muscle is supplied by the PIN, but it has some innervation from the radial nerve before the PIN branches off, so supination is usually not completely lost. The bicep brachii is supplied by the musculocutaneous nerve while the brachioradialis is supplied by the radial nerve.

 

Option C. Extension of elbow: The primary elbow extensor muscles are triceps brachii and anconeus. It is supplied by the radial nerve, thus it remains unaffected in PIN palsy. 

 

Option D. Wrist drop: Wrist drop is a disorder caused by radial nerve palsy. Because of the radial nerve's innervation of the extensor muscles of the wrist and digits, those whose radial nerve function has been compromised cannot actively extend them. As such, the hand hangs flaccidly in a position of flexion when the patient attempts to bring the arm to a horizontal position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PIN palsy is a neuropathic compression of the posterior interosseous nerve where it passes through the radial tunnel.
  • This may result in paresis or paralysis of the digital and thumb extensor muscles, resulting in an inability to extend the thumb and fingers at their MCP joints.
  • Wrist extension is preserved due to the action of the extensor carpi radialis longus innervated by the radial nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following substances can be used for new bone formation in cases of non-union fracture?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone morphogenetic protein

 

PROPERTIES OF GRAFT MATERIALS

 

 

 

  • Atrophic non union (absent callus, poor bone biology, lack of blood supply) are fixed by internal fixation with biologic stimulation.
  • Biologic stimulation is done with bone graft and bone morphogenetic protein (BMP).
  • Although the gold standard in nonunion therapy is the transplantation of autologous bone graft, missing bone regeneration subsequent to transplantation of autologous bone graft poses a serious disadvantage for the patients. Therefore, in the last few years, this therapy was combined with the application of bone morphogenetic protein-7 (BMP-7).
  • Use of BMP-7 is approved for tibial non-unions.
  • BMP-2 is approved for 1 level degenerative disk disease in spinal fusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium phosphate. Calcium Phosphate Cement is a useful bone substitute for benign bone tumor surgery. It provides excellent osteoconductivity and long-lasting stability without internal fixation.

 

Option B. Caclium sulphate. Calcium sulfate is a synthetic ceramic bone graft substitutes which has an osteoconductive property. It is a bio-inert material which gets resorbed over a period of weeks and fibrovascular tissue takes its place which eventually allows neovascularisation and bone formation within the area. Use of calcium sulfate as a bone graft substitutes avoids the complications and morbidity associated with autograft like infection.

 

Option C. PMMA. Polymethylmethacrylate is one of the most enduring materials in orthopaedic surgery. It has a central role in the success of total joint replacement and is also used in newer techniques such as percutaneous vertebroplasty and kyphoplasty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BMP helps in bone formation and repair. Thus, for the union of non-united fractures by surgery, it is used as an autograft material.

questions.text: An elderly patient presented with fracture following a trivial fall. X-ray is shown below. Determine the reason of fracture in the patient. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bone Metastasis

 

  • The skeleton is the third most common site of metastasis after lung and liver.
  • Bone metastases cause bone destruction increasing the patient’s risk for atraumatic fracture. 
  • The presentation is dependent on the site of the disease however; constant pain is a prevalent symptom. 
  • Fractures of the thoracic and lumbar spine present with pain characteristically worse with sitting or standing. 
  • Pathologic fractures result in significant morbidities resulting from pain, radiculopathy (e.g., sciatica with pelvic fracture), deformities, and immobility. 
  • Plain radiography detects osteolytic lesions, but they may not be apparent until they are > 1-2 cm with loss of 50% of the bone mineral content at the site of disease. 
  • Osteolytic lesions are seen as thinning of trabeculae and ill-defined margins on radiographs, while sclerotic lesions appear nodular and well-circumscribed as a result of thickened trabeculae. 
  • Plain films tend to be insensitive, especially in detecting bone metastases and with asymptomatic and subtle lesions. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubercular Hip: Tuberculosis of the hip typically presents with insidious pain and limited range of motion, often over a prolonged period. A fracture due to a trivial fall is less characteristic.

 

Option B. Brown Tumour: Brown tumors are a consequence of hyperparathyroidism. They typically present with pathological fractures, but the X-ray appearance would usually show distinct radiolucent areas. The pattern of the fracture and appearance of the lesion in the provided X-ray are not suggestive of brown tumor.

 

Option D. Eosinophilic Granuloma: This condition often affects children or young adults and manifests as a localized bone lesion. It is usually a benign lytic lesion. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most likely diagnosis for the provided x-ray and patient’s history of fracture following a fall is bone metastasis. 
  • Metastatic bone disease, common in elderly patients, often weakens the bone, making it prone to fracture, even with minimal trauma. 
  • The X-ray might show subtle changes suggestive of bone loss and/or a lesion, which could indicate the presence of metastatic disease.

questions.text: In case of meniscal tear, in which of the following zones the healing is best seen? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red zone

 

VASCULAR REGIONS IN THE MENISCUS

 

  • Vascular supply to the menisci originates predominantly from the inferior and superior lateral and medial geniculate arteries via the perimeniscal capillary plexus.
  • At birth, the entire meniscus is vascular. Following birth, the menisci become increasingly avascular (decrease in vascularity continues up to age 9 years), so by maturity only the peripheral 10-25% of the tissue is perfused.
  • In adults, only 10-25% of lateral meniscus and 10-30% of medial meniscus is vascular.
  • This gives rise to 3 distinct regions of the menisci: 
    • The peripheral relatively vascularized region called the red-red zone (Zone 1)
    • The completely avascular inner 2/3rd zone is known as the white-white zone (Zone 3)
    • Zone of transition between the two (border of avascular and vascular area), which is called the red-white zone (Zone 2)
       
  • There is a direct relationship between the vascularization and capacity of the tissue to heal, predisposing the white-white zone to permanent posttraumatic and degenerative lesions.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Red-white zone. The red-white zone is the middle third with less vascularization but can heal through sometimes.

 

Option C. White zone. The white-white zone has no blood capillaries at all and therefore, cannot heal. They usually require surgery to remove or cut out the torn portion of the meniscus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The red zone of the meniscus is the most vascularized zone.
  • Any injury at this zone will heal on its own, without a requirement of surgery.

questions.text:
What is the sequence of performing a Thomas test?(INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Passive flexion of affected hip
  2. Overcorrection on the normal side
  3. Measure the flexion angle
  4. Checking for lumbar lordosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV, II, I, III

 

THOMAS TEST

 

  • It is used to assess for hip flexion contracture and psoas syndrome.
  • It is especially useful when the fixed flexion deformity is masked by excessive lordosis.
  • Steps:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of performing the Thomas test is:

 

Checking for lumbar lordosis

                        ↓

Overcorrection on the normal side

                        ↓

Passive flexion of affected hip

                        ↓

Measure the flexion angle

questions.text: An old lady complains of chronic backpain since a few months. X-ray is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

  • The image shows Codfish Vertebra seen in Osteoporosis.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Spondylolysis. Spondylolysis is characterized by presence of bony defect at pars interarticularis, which can result in spondylolisthesis. Most common vertebra having spondylolysis is L5. High incidence of spondylolysis in gymnasts and other athlete’s suggest repetitive injury, which may be the contributing mechanism. Patient aged over 50 years are usually women. They always have backache or sciatica and claudication due to spinal stenosis. On examination, buttocks look flat, the sacrum appears to extend to the waist and transverse loin creases are seen. Step off can be felt when the fingers are run down the spine, secondary to prominent spinous processes of L5. With more severe slippage, the lumbosacral junction becomes more kyphotic and the trunk appears shortened with the rib cage approaching the iliac crest. Percentage of slippage as measured on lateral view and oblique radiograph demonstrate collar or broken neck on the scottie dog in spondylolysis.

 

 

Collar or broken neck on the scottie dog appearance

 

Option C. Spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis is the forward slippage of one vertebrae upon another. It nearly always occurs between L5 and S1 (most common) or L4 and L5. Patient aged over 50 years are usually women. They always have backache or sciatica and claudication due to spinal stenosis. The extent of slippage may not be correlated with severity of pain. On examination, buttocks look flat, the sacrum appears to extend to the waist and transverse loin creases are seen. Step off can be felt when the fingers are run down the spine, secondary to prominent spinous processes of L5. With more severe slippage, the lumbosacral junction becomes more kyphotic and the trunk appears shortened with the rib cage approaching the iliac crest. Percentage of slippage is measured on lateral view and oblique radiograph demonstrate beheaded dog in spondylolisthesis (Beheaded Scottish terrier sign).

 

 

Beheaded dog appearance

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis. It is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. The bone contains increased number of osteoclasts but these do not resorb bone as evidenced by absence of ruffled borders and clear zones and are unable to respond to PTH. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones (marble bone disease). Malignant osteopetrosis (congenital form) is autosomal recessive (AR, 11q13) and late onset osteopetrosis tarda (adolescence/adult form) is AD (1P 21). Intermediate form is AR. Autosomal dominant osteopetrosis is diagnosed in adult asymptomatic patients. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures, premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Autosomal recessive malignant osteopetrosis presents at birth or in early infancy because of obliteration of marrow cavity by bony overgrowth, resulting in inability of bone marrow to participate in hematopoiesis. Pancytopenia develops resulting in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive. Fragile, brittle bones, and Pathological fractures are seen. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Rugger jersey spine is seen on radiograph. Treatment is bone marrow transplant.

 

 

 

Marble bone appearance

 

 

Rugger jersey spine

 

Educational objective:

 

The image shown in the question is the radiological feature seen in osteoporosis, called as codfish appearance of vertebra.

questions.text: Treatment of open fracture of femur: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open reduction and external fixation 

 

OPEN FRACTURES

 

  • An open fracture occurs when the bone breaks through the skin. 
  • These typically result from high-energy injuries and are often associated with significant damage to the surrounding soft tissues and contamination of the wound. 
  • These injuries are classified into three types according to the Gustillo-Anderson Classification:

 

 

  • All open fractures are emergencies.
  • These injuries require immediate administration of antibiotics and irrigation and debridement of the wound. 
  • The goal of the treatment is to achieve fracture healing and to prevent wound infections and osteomyelitis. 
  • They are frequently associated with injuries to surrounding vessels and nerves, which must be addressed as well. 
  • When the wound is contaminated, an external fixator is initially used. 
  • Early coverage of the wound is important to avoid infection. 
  • Immediately debride the wound of contaminated and devitalized tissue, copiously irrigate, and repeat debridement within 24-72 hours (Delayed wound closure is preferable).
  • Type and method of fixation:

 

 

  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin –Ilizarov fixator.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Closed reduction and internal fixation: Closed reduction is not done for an open fracture. An open fracture inherently involves a break in the skin and contamination. It requires surgical exploration, debridement, and irrigation of the wound in the operating room. Attempting a closed reduction would significantly increase the risk of deep infection (osteomyelitis). Internal fixation (e.g., with an intramedullary nail) can be used for less severe open fractures (Gustilo-Anderson Type I, II, and sometimes IIIA), after thorough open debridement. However, the combination with closed reduction makes this option incorrect for an open fracture.

 

Option D. Closed reduction and external fixation: Closed reduction is incorrect for an open fracture due to the necessity of open wound management. External fixation is a valid and often preferred method of stabilization for open fractures, particularly severe ones or as a temporary measure. However, the initial phase must involve open management of the wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The open fractures are best treated with open reduction and external fixation with the use of external fixators like ilizarov fixator.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presented in clinic with low back pain & stiffness since 2 months. Modified Schober's test done was positive. An X-ray was done as shown in the image. Most likely diagnosis is:(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
    • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
    • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
    • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
    • Clinical Presentation:
      • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15 - 25 years.
      • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness and improves with activity.
      • Hip and shoulder joint arthritis may occur. Peripheral joints may also be involved in some.
      • Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation.
  • Diagnostic Criteria: Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these three:
      • Inflammatory back pain
      • Limited chest expansion (<5 cm at 4th ICS) {not a reliable criterion in elderly because of pulmonary disorders}
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (Schober test/Modified Schober test).
    • Inflammatory back pain is classified if 4/5 are present
      1. Pain for > 3 months
      2. <40 years age
      3. Insidious onset
      4. Pain improves with exercise
      5. Pain at night
  • Spine radiograph shows:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.
    • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
    • Calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacrotuberous ligaments.

 

 

Dagger sign

 

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons & ligaments.
  • Trolley/Tram-track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) are seen.

 

 

Trolley track sign

 

  • Bamboo spine  appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Bamboo spine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e. there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phoshatase levels. Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to Dexa scan of 30 year old individual and T score is calculated. WHO classification of values in a DEXA scan are T score 0 to –1 is normal, T score –1 to –2.5 is osteopenia, and T score less than –2.5 is osteoporosis. The patient is usually asymptomatic until a vertebral fracture occurs. The x-ray of the spine shows codfish vertebrae.

 

 

Option C. PIVD. Lumbar Disc Herniation is a very common cause of low back pain and unilateral leg pain, known as radiculopathy. The patient usually presents with decreased lumbar movement, paraspinal muscle spasm. The provocative tests like straight leg raise is positive. The x-ray shows decreased space between the affected vertebrae due to disc prolapse.

 

 

Option D. Osteoarthritis. Spine osteoarthritis is the presence of disc degeneration and osteophyte formation. The typical presentation of patients with symptomatic osteoarthritis of the spine is pain, stiffness, and motion restriction, which is commonly accompanied by referred pain. The lumbar spine provides pain located in the buttock and thigh region. Lumbar spine osteoarthritis can be associated with radicular pain above the knee.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows the bamboo spine appearance which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Out of the diagnostic criterias for ankylosing spondylitis, one of the criteria is the positive modified Schober’s test i.e., limited lumbar spine movement in saggital and frontal planes.

questions.text: Haglund’s deformity is seen in which joint?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ankle

 

HAGLUND DEFORMITY

 

  • Haglund deformity is prominent Calcaneal tuberosity and overlying bursitis (retro-calcaneal).
  • It is a bony enlargement formed at posterosuperior aspect of calcaneum along with retrocalcaneal bursitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Haglund deformity is seen at the ankle joint.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented with chronic low back pain and early morning stiffness since last 2 years, which is also associated with bilateral heel pain. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints; B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. TB spine. In pott’s spine, the commonest & usually the 1st symptom is back pain, which is usually minimal. Tenderness is the earliest sign. Twist tenderness for Anterior elements is more significant as disease is anteriorly involving the vertebral body (paradiscal). Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When bending forward, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine are in extension (Coin test). Earliest sign in patient with neurological deficit is increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response (twitching of muscles can be seen even earlier). The Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm. There is reduction of intervertebral disk space and osteoporosis of two adjacent vertebrae, sometimes with fuzziness of the endplates. Paraspinal abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.

 

 

Option C. Mechanical back pain. Mechanical back strain is a subtype of back pain where the etiology is the spine, intervertebral discs, or the surrounding soft tissues. Lower back is usually affected the most. More than 80% of people will suffer from low back pain during their lifetime. There is a higher prevalence among women and people ages 40-80 years. Acute mechanical back strains may be triggered by physical or non-physical activity, with lifting being the most commonly recalled event. The patient complaints of axial lumbosacral pain and/or radicular pain into the lower extremity. Low back pain does not necessarily correlate with imaging findings. Plain radiograph is suitable to assess bony abnormalities or fractures.

 

Option D. Prolapsed intervertebral disc. The commonest site of disc prolapse is lumbar spine. In more than 95% of cases lumbar disc herniation are localized at L4-L5 (50% cases) and L5-S1 (45% cases). The next commonest site of intervertebral disc prolapse is lower cervical spine (C5-C6). Lumbar disc is dehydrated hence more prone. Small herniation of nucleus pulposus produce Schmorl’s nodules. Degenerated disc is extruded posteriorly in three patterns: Central, Paracentral (annulus bulges to one side of posterior longitudinal ligament – most common type and produced unilateral radicular symptoms), and Far lateral disc herniation (bulge is within or just lateral to neural foramina).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of chronic low back pain, early morning stiffness, and bilateral heel pain are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis which involves the enthesis of the body.

choices.text: ACL and medial collateral ligament injury
Lateral collateral ligament injury
Medial meniscus injury

questions.text: The injury shown in the radiograph can result in: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ACL injury

 

SEGOND FRACTURE

 

  • Segond fracture is an avulsion fracture of the knee that involves the lateral aspect of the tibial plateau and is very frequently (»75% of cases) associated with disruption of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).
  • On the frontal knee radiograph, it may appear as a curvilinear or elliptic bone fragment projected parallel to the lateral aspect of the tibial plateau, referred to as the lateral capsular sign.

 

 

  • Contrary to the more common causes of an ACL tear, which typically involves valgus stress, a Segond fracture usually occurs as a result of internal rotation and varus stress.
  • Treatment:
  • Although the fracture itself is small, the extensive ligamentous injury associated with it usually requires surgical intervention.
  • Spontaneous healing of the Segond fracture may occur following ACL reconstruction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows Segond fracture, which is frequently seen with ACL injuries.

questions.text: Hyperextension at MCP joint and flexion at IP joint occurs due to involvement of which muscle?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lumbricals and interossei

 

  • The Lumbricals (+ interossei) paralysis causes claw hand (MCP hyperextension and IP joint flexion).

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hyperextension of the MCP joint and flexion of the IP joint is seen in the claw hand deformity due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand i.e., the lumbricals and the interossei.

questions.text: Patient had difficulty in walking upstairs. When he was made to bear weight on right lower limb, the left-sided pelvis dropped down, but when he was standing on the left lower limb, the right-sided pelvis moved up. Which of the following is the likely lesion? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right superior gluteal nerve palsy

 

WADDLING (GLUTEAL OR TRENDELENBURG) GAIT

 

  • This gait is characteristic of the gluteal muscle weakness that is seen in the progressive muscular dystrophies, but it occurs as well in chronic forms of spinal muscular atrophy, in certain inflammatory myopathies, lumbosacral nerve root compression, and with congenital dislocation of the hips.
  • It can also occur in neurogenic conditions in which the superior gluteal nerve is involved.
  • In normal walking, as weight is placed alternately on each leg, the hip is fixated by the gluteal muscles, particularly the gluteus medius, allowing for a slight rise of the opposite hip and tilt of the trunk to the weight-bearing side.
  • With weakness of the glutei, however, there is a failure to stabilize the weight-bearing hip, causing it to bulge outward and the opposite side of the pelvis to drop, with inclination of the trunk to that side.
  • The alternation in lateral trunk movements results in the roll or waddle.
  • With unilateral gluteal weakness, often the result of damage to the first sacral nerve root, tilting and dropping of the pelvis (“pelvic ptosis”) is apparent on only one side as the patient overlifts the leg when walking.
  • In several of the muscular dystrophies, an accentuation of lumbar lordosis is often seen.
  • Also, childhood cases may be complicated by muscular contractures, leading to an equinovarus position of the foot, so that the waddle is combined with walking on the toes (“toe walking”).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left superior gluteal nerve palsy. When the patient is standing on one leg, the opposite pelvis should be lifted upwards by abduction of the ipsilateral hip joint, in a normal patient. When the abductors are weak due to superior gluteal nerve paresis, the pelvis will sag, called positive Trendelenburg sign. In a patient with a positive Trendelenburg sign, the pelvis sags toward the normal unsupported side, which is the swing leg. When the left superior gluteal nerve is affected, on standing on the left lower limb, the right side pelvis will drop and when the patient stands on the right leg, the left side pelvis will be lifted up.

 

Option C. Right inferior gluteal nerve palsy. The inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle. It is therefore, responsible for extending the trunk from a forward bending position and extending the hip from sitting-to-standing or during stair-climbing or rising from a squatted position. The nerve does not confer any sensation. Injury to this nerve is most commonly iatrogenic in origin and is the most at risk nerve during total hip arthroplasty via a posterior approach. Injury typically leads to an altered gait pattern known as gluteus maximus ‘lurch’. The sequelae of nerve injury are denervation of the ipsilateral gluteus maximus muscle. The lurching gait results from the weakening or absence of an ipsilateral hip extension. Clinically, patients may also report wasting of the ipsilateral gluteus maximus muscle and loss of the defined shape to the affected buttock. In a normal gait cycle, the gluteus maximus begin to contract at the moment of the ipsilateral heel-strike to initiate ipsilateral hip extension. In inferior gluteal nerve injury, the trunk will extend when the heel strikes on the ground on the affected side to compensate for weak/absent hip extension. This backward trunk lurch is present in the whole stance phase of the gait cycle and locks the hip in extension. In some cases, the hamstrings muscle compensates to an extent. Therefore, in the right inferior gluteal nerve palsy, the right side hip will not extend during the initial heel strike and the trunk will lean backwards/extend.

 

Option D. Left inferior gluteal nerve palsy. In the injury of left sided gluteal nerve, the left hip will not extend during the initial heel strike, leading to backward lurch or extension of the trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On standing on the right lower limb, the left side pelvis drops and while standing on the left leg, the right side pelvis lifted up. This is indicative of right superior gluteal nerve palsy. This sign is called Trendelenburg Sign.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient complains of frequent episodes of red, painful eyes, stiffness, and back pain. He has sacroiliitis and anterior uveitis, according to the examination. Which HLA is frequently involved among the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HLA B27

 

The patient's symptoms of red painful eyes, stiffness, back pain, sacroiliitis, and anterior uveitis strongly indicates ankylosing spondylitis. 

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS (AS)

 

  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, a genetically determined generalized chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the axial skeleton (sacroiliac joint and spine) with variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints. 
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy. 
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Males are affected more frequently than females (2:1 to 10:1)
    • Age of onset is between 15–25 years (late adolescence and early adulthood).
    • The initial symptom is usually dull pain, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, accompanied by low back morning stiffness of few hours that improves with activity and returns following rest.
    • Question mark (?) posture can occur due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis. 
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late.
    • The most common extra-articular manifestation is acute anterior uveitis (iridocyclitis) occurring in 30%. Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
  • Diagnostic Criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria must be one of the 3:
      1. Inflammatory back pain
      2. Limited chest expansion (<5 cm at 4th ICS) 
      3. Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (Schober test/Modified Schober test).
    • Inflammatory back pain is classified if 4/5 are present
      1. Pain for > 3 months
      2. <40 years of age
      3. Insidious onset
      4. Pain improves with exercise
      5. Pain at night
  • Etiology and Pathogenesis:
    • > 90% of AS patients are HLA-B27 positive. 
    • The enthesis is the primary site of pathology particularly in pelvis and spine.
    • It is associated with prominent edema of adjacent bone marrow and is characterized by erosive lesions that eventually undergo ossification.
    • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA DR4: HLA DR4 is associated with autoimmune diseases. It is more strongly linked to rheumatoid arthritis and type 1 diabetes.

 

Option B. HLA DR3: HLA DR3 is associated with autoimmune diseases like type 1 diabetes, Graves' disease, and celiac disease.

 

Option C. HLA DQB1: HLA DQB1 is also linked to autoimmune diseases, particularly type 1 diabetes and celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The patient's symptoms of red painful eyes, stiffness, back pain, sacroiliitis, and anterior uveitis strongly indicates ankylosing spondylitis. 
  • HLA-B27 is strongly associated with this condition. 
  • Other HLA types are linked to various autoimmune diseases, HLA-B27 is the most strongly associated with this specific presentation.

questions.text: A patient had a femur fracture for which internal fixation was done. Two days later, the patient developed sudden onset shortness of breath with low grade fever. What is the likely cause? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fat embolism

 

FAT EMBOLISM

  • Fracture Femur with Breathlessness after 48 hours – think of fat embolism!
  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma.
  • Fat embolism syndrome (FES) reflects a serious systemic manifestation as a consequence to these emboli.
  • Fat originates from the site of trauma, particularly from the injured marrow.
  • Fat globules > 10 mm are considered significant.
  • Salient Features:
    • Presence of fat globules in pulmonary circulation.
    • Precipitated by physical trauma such as fracture of long bones, soft tissue trauma, and burns.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Clinical signs and symptoms develop after a asymptomatic latent period of about 12 - 48 hours.
    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).
    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:
      • Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea.
      • Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation.
      • Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder.
  • Diagnosis:
    • FES is distinct from the presence of fat emboli.
    • Symptoms usually occur 1-3 days after a traumatic injury and are predominantly pulmonary (shortness of breath, hypoxemia), neurological (agitation, delirium, or coma), dermatological (petechial rash), and hematological (anemia, low platelets).
  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Treatment:
    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood.
    • If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation.
    • Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.
    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg.
    • O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.
    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax. A pneumothorax is a collection of air outside the lung but within the pleural cavity. It occurs when air accumulates between the parietal and visceral pleurae inside the chest. The air accumulation can apply pressure on the lung and make it collapse. Causes of traumatic pneumothorax are penetrating or blunt trauma, rib fracture, diving or flying. While it can cause shortness of breath, it is less likely to occur specifically after femur fracture fixation unless there was a procedure complication.

 

Option B. Pleural effusion. Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in between the parietal and visceral pleura, called the pleural cavity. It can occur by itself or can be the result of surrounding parenchymal disease like infection, malignancy, or inflammatory conditions. While it can cause respiratory symptoms, it is less likely to occur suddenly after femur fracture fixation unless there are other complicating factors.

 

Option D. Congestive cardiac failure. Congestive heart failure (CHF) is a complex clinical syndrome characterized by inefficient myocardial performance, resulting in compromised blood supply to the body. CHF results from any disorder that impairs ventricular filling or ejection of blood to the systemic circulation. Patients usually present with fatigue and dyspnea, reduced exercise tolerance, and systemic or pulmonary congestion. While congestive heart failure can cause shortness of breath, it is less likely to occur suddenly after a femur fracture fixation unless the patient has pre-existing heart conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fat embolism is the most common complication of femur fracture.
  • It usually presents 48 hours after the injury with breathlessness and low grade fever.
  • The patient  remains asymptomatic in the initial 12-48 hours.

questions.text: Which type of translocation is seen in diaphyseal tumor with small blue round cells? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T11, 22

 

The question refers to Ewing's sarcoma, a type of malignant tumor that typically affects the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones, particularly in children and young adults. The tumor is characterized by small, round, blue cells when viewed under a microscope. A hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma is the t(11;22) translocation, which fuses the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 with the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. This translocation results in the production of an abnormal protein that drives the cancer.

 

This translocation, t(11;22), is highly specific for Ewing's sarcoma and is used as a diagnostic marker.

 

Mic 2 (CD99) – Most specific marker for Ewing’s sarcoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EWSR1, WT1: This combination is incorrect for Ewing's sarcoma. While EWSR1 is involved, WT1 is a gene associated with Wilms' tumor, a kidney cancer, and is not involved in Ewing's sarcoma.

 

Option C. T15,17: This translocation is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), not Ewing's sarcoma. The fusion of the PML and RARA genes occurs in APL.

 

Option D. T2,13: This translocation is associated with alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, another type of soft tissue tumor, but not with Ewing's sarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The t(11;22) translocation is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma, a diaphyseal tumor with small, round, blue cells, making it a crucial genetic marker for diagnosis.

questions.text: Which is the most common Osteoporotic fracture site?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertebral fracture

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • The fractures that are most common (in decreasing order) are vertebral fracture > hip (neck femur) > lower end radius.
  • Most of the vertebral fractures are asymptomatic and are identified incidentally during radiograph for other purpose.
  • Few of these present as backache of varying degree.
  • Up to 70 years of age, the order of fracture incidence is vertebral > Colle’s.
  • Overall and in > 70 years of age, it is vertebral > Hip > Colle’s.
  • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse), codfish appearance and pencilling of vertebrae.

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra (Biconcave vertebra)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intertrochanteric fracture: These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. These patients are also typically older than patients who suffer femoral neck fractures. In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism. The femur is the second most common site of fracture in the osteoporotic patients.

 

Option C. Femoral shaft fracture: Femoral shaft fractures can result from high or low energy mechanisms. The most common causes include automobile accidents, falls from heights, ground-level falls in individuals with osteoporosis, and gunshots. About 75% fractures are caused by high energy mechanisms. Other less common causes are atypical fractures from bisphosphonate use, pathologic fractures through a bone lesion, insufficiency fractures from osteoporosis, and stress fractures from overuse in athletes.

 

Option D. Subtrochanteric fracture: Subtrochanteric fractures are mainly seen in 2 patient populations: spiral fractures in osteoporotic patients and atypical insufficiency fractures that happen after no to low-energy trauma (e.g., patients who use long-term bisphosphate therapy). But femur involvement is the second common site in osteoporosis for fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site for osteoporotic fractures is the vertebral column followed by femur (mainly neck) and lower end of the radius.

questions.text: In spine straightening surgeries, screws used for fixation are inserted through which of the following parts of the vertebra? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pedicle

 

  • Spinal instrumentation (rods,  screws, hooks, etc.) are applied to the region of the spine to be corrected through transpedicular route and bone graft is added. 

  • In the spine straightening surgery, to stabilize the spine, screws are placed on the pedicles of the vertebral bone. 

 

 

  • Hooks may also be used in conjunction with screws, and are placed around the pedicle or around the lamina.

  • Rods are then secured in the screw heads, connecting adjacent vertebrae. 

  • The rods are shaped to match the desired corrected curvature of the spine, and are attached to the screws and/or hooks.

  • Bone graft material is placed around the final assembly and as the spine heals, spinal fusion is accomplished by bone growth between the vertebrae. This bone growth permanently fixes the spine in the desired position. The implants hold the spine in the corrected position while the spine fuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pedicle of the vertebra is the area used to fixate the screws through during the spine straightening surgeries for scoliosis.

questions.text: Which of the following condition will cause intermittent breaking of long bones in a child? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Osteogenesis Imperfecta

 

OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA

 

  • It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative and qualitative defect in type I collagen formation.
  • There is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen.
  • Most common cause of multiple fractures in childhood.
  • It is also known as Lobstein-Vrolik brittle bone disease.
  • It is inherited from a parent in autosomal dominant (AD) fashion, or may occur as spontaneous mutation, or, rarely as autosomal recessive (AR) trait.
  • Clinical features:
    • The defining clinical feature is osteopenia, causing repeated propensity to fracture, generally after minor trauma and often without much pain or swelling.
    • According to the severity of disease, fractures may occur in uterus, at birth, or after birth prior to or after walking age.
    • Lower limb fractures are more common than upper limb.
    • Femur is commonest bone fractured followed by tibia.
    • Frequency of fractures decline sharply after adolescence or puberty, although it may rise again in postmenopausal (climacteric) women.
    • Hyperlaxity of ligaments, with resultant hypermobility of joint is common.
    • Rarely recurrent dislocation of patella, radial head and hip joint dislocation and DDH can occur.
    • Blue/gray sclera due to uveal pigment visible through thin collagen layer.
    • Deafness due to otosclerosis/pressure on auditory nerve
    • Dentinogenesis imperfect/crumbling of teeth i.e., deciduous and permanent teeth break easily and become prone to carries. Lower incisors severely affected.
    • Skin becomes thin and translucent. Subcutaneous hemorrhages may occur.
    • Muscles are hypotonic due to multiple fractures and deformities.
       
  • Prenatal diagnosis: Abnormal Pro a chain
  • Radiological features:
    • Wormian bones (detached portions of primary ossification centers of adjacent membrane bones) are seen in skull X-ray. It should be more than 10 in number, measure at least 6 × 4 mm, and arranged in mosaic pattern.
    • Ring-shaped epiphysis is seen
    • Skeleton: White crumpled-bone shaped not maintained

 

 

  • Classification: SILLENCE classification
  • Treatment: 
    • Bisphosphonates to decrease osteoclastic bone resorption
    • Ideal treatment: replace COLIAI or COLIA2 gene.
       
  • SOFIELD MILLER surgery (SEEKH KEBAB surgery)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achondroplasia. It is a primary defect of endochondral bone formation. Autosomal dominant but 80% are spontaneous mutations. It is the effect of excessive growth hormone on the mature skeleton. Paternal age >36 year is linked with new mutation. It is most common form of disproportionate dwarfism. Disproportionate rhizomelic micromelia is most severe in proximal limbs. Trunk height is be normal, but arm span and standing height are diminished. Skull is large with prominent forehead (frontal bossing), saddle-shaped nose (flat and depressed nasal bridge), small maxilla, prominent mandibles and normal dentition. The patients have normal intelligence, trident hand (separation between middle and ring fingers) and starfish hand (middle finger shorter). The vertebrae shows short interpedicular distance, bullet shape. The pelvis appears like a champagne glass (pelvic width > depth). Hooked vertebra are seen.

 

 

 

Option B. Marfan syndrome. It is the Fibrillin 1 defect. There is a disproportionate increase in the height. The limbs are long and there is arachnodactyly (fingers and hand are long and have spider-like appearance). Scoliosis, Pectus excavatum/Pectus carinatum, Hyperlaxity, High-arched palate, Pes planus, and Hammer toes are seen. Early OA is a feature. Ghent criterion is used for diagnosis of Marfan syndrome.

 

 

Option D. Cretinism. Cretinism is a condition of severely stunted physical and mental growth due to untreated congenital deficiency of thyroid hormones (congenital hypothyroidism). Congenital hypothyroidism can be endemic, genetic, or sporadic. Sporadic and genetic cretinism results from abnormal development, or function of the foetal thyroid gland. Cretinism has been almost completely eliminated in developed countries by early diagnosis by newborn screening schemes and iodine supplementation programs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intermittent breaking of long bones in children is a feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: Match the following tumours with their treatment choices: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-a, 2-c, 3-b, 4-d

 

 

1. GIANT CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Radiological features: Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with  hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

2. OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.
    • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic  bone may be seen outside the involved bone.
       
  • Management:
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.
       

3. SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Simple bone cysts are a common pseudotumor of bone.
  • They are found in the proximal humerus in 50% of cases and in the upper femur in 25%.
  • The calcaneus and pelvis are also uniquely common locations.
  • Patients are asymptomatic until a pathologic fracture occurs.
  • Radiographs typically show a solitary cyst that is centrally located in the metaphyseal area and has marked thinning of the adjacent cortical bone and a pseudoloculated appearance.
  • If there is associated fracture, radiographs may show the characteristic “fallen leaf” sign.
  • In weight-bearing bones, such as the proximal femur, lesions should be treated aggressively.
  • Management:
    • Initial management usually involves aspiration/injection with either bone marrow or corticosteroid.
    • The injections are carried out with bone biopsy needles and are repeated three to five times at intervals of 2 to 3 months, depending on the radiographic response.
    • Curettage and bone grafting may also be an effective modality.

 

4. OSTEOID OSTEOMA

 

  • The most common benign osteoid-forming tumor is the osteoid osteoma, accounting for 10% of all benign bone tumors.
  • The proximal femur is the most common location.
  • Dull, aching, nocturnal pain is characteristic, and it is commonly relieved entirely by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) secondary to a high concentration of prostaglandins in the nidus.
  • Radiographic Feature:
    • Central, lytic nidus usually 1 cm or less in diameter. The more common cortically-based lesion exhibits extensive reactive sclerosis, creating a fusiform bulge on the bone surface. If the nidus is close to, or actually in, a joint, as in a femoral neck lesion, the resulting reactive synovitis may mimic a pyarthrosis or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Technetium bone scans are invariably positive. A CT scan is recommended to better anatomically locate the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
    • In the spine, the typical location for an osteoid osteoma is in the posterior elements.
       
  • Management:
    • Many cases of osteoid osteoma are stage 1 lesions and can be treated symptomatically with aspirin or NSAIDs until they spontaneously resolve. If the patient fails such treatment, intervention is warranted.
    • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation has emerged as the preferred treatment modality in many cases.
    • If open surgical excision is undertaken, the entire nidus must be eradicated.

questions.text: The last symptoms to develop in compartment syndrome is: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulselessness

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.

  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).

  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.

  • Clinical Features:

  • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.

  • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) – 1st sign.

  • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome. The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis. 

  • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.

  • Acute compartment syndrome presents with the following 5 Ps:

 

 

  • Paralysis and Pulselessness are considered late and ominous signs, indicating severe and irreversible tissue damage. 
  • Paralysis and pulselessness signifies that the condition has progressed significantly, indicating permanent injury.
  • Pulselessness generally represents a more critical and terminal stage of circulatory compromise.
  • It implies complete or near-complete cessation of blood flow, which is ultimately the most severe and final physiological sign of impending tissue death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain on passive stretch. Pain and resistance to the passive stretch is the first sign of the compartment syndrome. 

 

Option B. Paralysis. Paralysis occurs in the late stages of the syndrome due to involvement of the nerves. 

 

Option C. Pallor. Pallor appears in the late stages and indicates irreversible muscle and nerve ischemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The last sign/symptom to appear in a compartment syndrome is pulselessness, as it signifies the most advanced stage of vascular compromise. 

  • While paralysis is also very late, the absence of a pulse is a definitive sign of severe, critical ischemia.

questions.text: Identify the most probable age of the child under POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act by looking at the X-ray below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 7 years

 

  • The X-ray shows 7 Carpal bones. Thus, minimum age is 5 here.
  • Also, pisiform is not seen. Hence, the age is between 5-12.
  • The best answer is 7 years as the normal age range for appearance of pisiform is 8-12 years.

 

BONE AGE

 

  • Left hand and wrist X-ray PA view – most commonly used for bone age assessment – Based on appearance of carpal bones
  • First to appear is Capitate, then in a counter-clockwise fashion except pisiform which is the last carpal bone to appear
  • Pisiform is ossified at the age of nine to 13 years as evident from different studies.
  • The appearance of ossification center of pisiform bone is one of the important evidence for estimating age among young children between nine to 13 years.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone.
  • Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to CTEV.(AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. 50% cases are in males and are bilateral
  2. Forefoot is adducted and supinated
  3. With Ponsetti technique, correction is up to 90%
  4. Equinus should be corrected first
questions.solution:
Ans. A. a, b, c are correct

 

  • CTEV is a congenital foot deformity characterized by several components:

    • Cavus: High arch

    • Adduction: Forefoot turned inward

    • Supination: Sole of the foot turned inward

    • Equinus: Plantarflexion 

    • Varus: Inversion of the heel

 

a. 50% cases are in males and are bilateral: 

 

  • Clubfoot is more common in males than females. The ratio is roughly 2:1. So, more than 50% of cases are in males.

  • Approximately 50% of all clubfoot cases occur in both feet (bilateral).

 

b. Forefoot is adducted and supinated:

 

  • This statement is correct. 

  • As mentioned earlier, forefoot adduction and supination are key components of the clubfoot deformity.

 

c. With Ponsetti technique, correction is up to 90%:

 

  • This statement is considered correct. 

  • The Ponseti method, a non-surgical treatment involving serial casting, has very high success rates, often reported around 90% or even higher when followed properly.

 

Other Option:

 

d. Equinus should be corrected first:

 

  • This statement is incorrect. 

  • The Ponseti method typically follows a specific sequence of correction:

    1. Cavus: Addressing the high arch first.

    2. Adduction and Supination: Correcting the inward turning of the forefoot.

    3. Varus: Correcting the inversion of the heel.

    4. Equinus: Addressing the plantarflexion of the foot, often as the final step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In CTEV, male children are more affected than females. 

  • 50% of cases of CTEV have bilateral lower limb involvement. 

  • There is forefoot adduction and supination in cases of CTEV. 

  • Ponseti method of conservative treatment gives correction of up to 90%. 

 

Equinus deformity is corrected at last, following the C-A-V-E sequence.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl arrives with several swellings and numerous brown rashes. Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Additionally, she has a past medical record of hypothyroidism. The provided image displays an X-ray of her femur. What is the probable diagnosis from the options provided?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. McCune-Albright syndrome

 

MCCUNE ALBRIGHT SYNDROME

 

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia (multiple bones involved)
  • Precocious puberty (endocrine abnormalities)
  • Cutaneous Pigmentation (café Au lait: coffee-colored spots)
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called “coast of Maine” bor- ders), as opposed to the smoothly marginated borders (“coast of California”) of the spots seen in neurofibromatosis.
  • Surgical treatment by curettage + bone grafting is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It is the idiopathic destruction of histiocytes. The disease has characteristics of both an abnormal reactive process and a neoplastic process. It may present initially as a rash, and can disseminate and involve bone marrow, lungs, liver, spleen, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal (GI) tract, and the pituitary gland. Histologically, the primary lesion is granulomatous with an influx of eosinophils, macrophages, T cells and multinucleated cells. The Birbeck granule is the microscopic hallmark of the disorder but may not be seen in lesions of the spleen, liver, and GI tract. The rash may be distinguished by the presence of petechiae, bloody crusting, or firmly indurated nodules. Bony involvement occurs in 78% patients. Solitary osseous lesions are incidentally found and may include the skull, hip/pelvis, femur, or ribs. This bony involvement may produce bone pain. In long bones, endosteal scalloping may be responsible for a “budding appearance”.

 

 

Endosteal scalloping presenting as budding appearance

 

Option C. Neuroma with bone involvement. Morton's neuroma is one of the most common pain syndromes affecting the forefoot. It is characterized by tenderness and burning pain in the plantar surface of the forefoot, with painful paresthesias in the two affected toes. This pain syndrome is caused by perineural fibrosis of the interdigital nerves. Although the nerves between the third and fourth toes are affected most commonly, the second and third toes and, rarely, the fourth and fifth toes can be affected as well. Patients may feel like they are walking with a stone in the shoe. The pain worsens with prolonged standing or walking for long distances and is exacerbated by poorly fitting or improperly padded shoes. Morton's neuroma is associated with wearing tight, narrow-toed shoes. On physical examination, pain can be reproduced by firmly squeezing the 2 metatarsal heads together with one hand while placing firm pressure on the interdigital space with the other hand. This maneuver is known as the Mulder sign. The patient exhibits an antalgic gait in an effort to reduce weight bearing during walking.

 

 

Option D. Papillary carcinoma of thyroid. Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is an epithelial malignancy showing follicular cell differentiation and nuclear features. It is the most frequent thyroid neoplasm. The tumor usually appears as an irregular solid mass. One key feature is the ability to invade adjacent structures like lymphatics. About 10% patients may present with metastatic disease at initial presentation. It usually presents as an asymptomatic thyroid mass with or without enlargement of regional (cervical) lymph nodes. Hoarseness and dysphagia occur in approximately 20% cases, signaling recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement with vocal cord paralysis or tracheal compression. Nodal metastases in the lateral neck are reported in 27% patients. The examination reveals a painless hard lesion of less than 5 cm. The mass is often fixed and has irregular borders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presentation of several swellings and numerous brown rashes represents café Au lait spots.
  • Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas.
  • There are irregularities in her biochemical values.
  • Presence of past medical history of hypothyroidism, and Shepherd crook deformity of femur in the given image, all point towards the McCune Albright Syndrome.

questions.text: What is the type of fracture shown in the X-ray of left shoulder? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neer classification grade 4

 

IMPORTANT CLASSIFICATIONS OF VARIOUS FRACTURES

 

 

NEER CLASSIFICATION OF PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • The classification consists of four major groupings, based on the number of displaced parts.
  • One-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 1 to 4 parts
    • No or minimal displacement (i.e. <1 cm and <45°)
    • Account for ~70-80% of all proximal humeral fractures and are almost always treated conservatively.

 

 

  • Two-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 2 to 4 parts
    • One part is displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°)
    • Four possible types of two-part fractures are: 
      1. Surgical neck: most common
      2. Greater tuberosity
        • Frequently seen in anterior shoulder dislocation
        • A lower threshold of displacement (>5 mm)
      3. Anatomical neck
      4. Lesser tuberosity: uncommon
    • These fractures account for approximately 20% of proximal humeral fractures.

 

 

  • Three-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 3 or 4 parts
    • Two parts are displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°)
    • 2 three-part fracture patterns are encountered:
      1. Greater tuberosity and shaft are displaced with respect to the lesser tuberosity and articular surface which remain together – most common pattern
      2. Lesser tuberosity and shaft are displaced with respect to the greater tuberosity and articular surface which remain together
    • These fractures account for approximately 5% of proximal humeral fractures.

 

 

  • Four-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves all 4 parts
    • Three parts are displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°) with respect to the 4th.
    • These fractures are uncommon (<1% of proximal humeral fractures).
    • This pattern has poor non-operative results as the articular surface is no longer attached to any parts of the humerus. This pattern has a high incidence of osteonecrosis. These fractures require operative management.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideberg classification grade 4. This system is used to classify the scapular fractures.

 

 

 

Option C. Garden classification grade 3. The Garden classification of subcapital femoral neck fractures is the most widely used. It predicts the development of osteonecrosis.

 

 

 

Option D. Schatzker classification grade 5. This is used to classify tibial plateau fracture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the grade 4 of the Neer’s classification of the proximal humerus fracture where all the fractured parts of the humerus are displaced.

questions.text:
An orthopedic surgeon plans to treat a Colle’s fracture. What are the steps involved in applying a cast for the same?(INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Palmar flexion
  2. Traction
  3. Ulnar deviation
  4. Application of plaster of Paris
questions.solution:
Ans. C) II, I, III, IV

 

COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corticocancellous junction.
  • It mostly occur in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women.
  • Symptoms and Signs:
    • Fracture of the distal radius, commonly referred to as a Colle’s fracture, is typically the result of a FOOSH injury (Fall on outstretched hand) with wrist in extension.
    • Patients present with swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness, and painful range of motion of the distal forearm.
    • On examination, the classic “dinner fork” deformity (dorsal displacement of the distal fragment and volar angulation of the distal intact radius with radial shortening) may be identified.

 

 

 

  • Complications:
