    • Early complications may include median nerve neuropathy, extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture, and compartment syndrome.
    • Late complications may include radiocarpal arthrosis, complex regional pain syndrome, cosmetic changes of the wrist, and fracture malunion or nonunion.
    • Finger stiffness is most common complication.
    • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
    • Colles fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Non-displaced extra-articular fractures are relatively stable and are treated non-operatively with a long-arm splint acutely  to allow for swelling, then transitioned to a short-arm cast.
    • The cast is applied on opposite forces to displacement. The position of immobilization is:

 

 

  • Displaced fractures should undergo an attempt at closed reduction followed by immobilization in a long-arm sugar-tong splint acutely.
  • Surgical fixation is indicated for distal radius fractures that fail to meet acceptable alignment criteria.
  • Various methods include closed reduction percutaneous  pinning, external fixation, and open reduction internal fixation (ORIF).
  • Technique of closed manipulation:
    • The muscles of forearm must be relaxed, either by general or regional anaesthesia.
    •  The surgeon grasps the injured hand as if he was ‘shaking hands’.

 

 

 

  • The first step is to disimpact the fragments which have often been driven together.
  • This is achieved by firm longitudinal traction to the hand against the counter-traction by an assistant who grasps the arm above the flexed elbow.
  • The surgeon now presses the distal fragment into palmar flexion and ulnar deviation using the thumb of his other hand.
  • As this is done, the patient’s hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.
  • A plaster cast is applied extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, maintaining

 

Educational Objective:

 

Steps of cast application in Colles fracture are:

 

Traction

↓

Palmar flexion

↓

Ulnar deviation

↓

Application of plaster of Paris

choices.text: Swan Neck deformity
Boutonniere deformity
Jersey Finger
Mallet Finger

questions.text: Identify the deformity:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Swan Neck deformity

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis: Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
    • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
      • Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles
      • Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint
      • Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
    • Others:
      • The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children.
      • Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
      • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
      • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis in patients of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:
    • Hand:
      • ‘Z-deformity’, i.e. radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of the digits, often with palmar subluxation of proximal phalanges.
      • Boutonniere deformity i.e. flexion contracture of PIP joints and hyperextension of DIP joints. It is due to rupture of extensor tendon.
      • Swan neck deformity i.e. hyperextension of PIP joints with compensatory flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints.

 

 

  • Elbow:
  • Flexion deformity
  • Knee:
  • Early: Flexion deformity
  • Late: Triple subluxation
  • Ankle:
  • Equinus deformity
  • Foot:
  • Hallux valgus, Hammer toe, etc.
  • Radiological Features:
  • Reduced joint space
  • Erosion of articular margins
  • Subchondral cysts
  • Juxta-articular rarefaction
  • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
  • Deformities of the hand and fingers

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Boutonniere deformity. It is the flexion contracture of PIP joints and hyperextension of DIP joints. It is due to rupture of extensor tendon.

 

 

Option C. Jersey finger. It is avulsion of FDP from distal phalanx. There is hyperextension of a flexed finger as in finger trapped in a jersey. Ring finger most commonly affected. Treatment is surgical.

 

 

Option D. Mallet finger. It is avulsion of extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal joint from its insertion at the base of distal phalanx. It may be due to direct trauma, but more often occurs when the finger tip is forcibly bent during active extension (i.e. sudden occurrence of passive flexion of distal interphalangeal joint). The terminal phalanx is flexed, but passive movement is normal. The proximal interphalangeal joint may become hyper- extended due to unbalanced extensor mechanism (Swan neck). Three types are a tendinous avulsion (X-ray is normal), a small flake of bone or a large dorsal bone fragment, (some times with subluxation of Joints).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The image shown in the question is of Swan Neck Deformity, which is seen in the cases of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st CMC with sparing of wrist and MCP is seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoarthritis

 

  • Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interphalangeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb) of hand.

 

 

  • Sparing of wrist and MCP is a feature of Osteoarthritis.
  • Rheumatoid Arthritis spares DIP and involves PIP, MCP and Wrist.
  • Diseases And Usual Joints Affected:

 

 

  • Characteristic Joint involvement in HANDS in various Arthritis:

 

 

 

 

The hand (to diagnose arthritis)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. Commonly Involved Joints (14 joints are used for diagnosis according to 1987 criterion – Right or left side) are Wrist joint, Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint, Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint, Elbow joint, Knee joint, Ankle joint, and Metatarsophalangeal joint. Less Commonly Involved joints are Upper cervical spine (facet joint) with Atlantoaxial subluxation, Hip joint, Temporomandibular joint, Subtalar and forefoot joints. Usually, DIP is not involved but is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops. The involvement in late stages is due to the pull of tendons/soft tissues in these deformities. Lumbar Spine is Usually Spared in RA.

 

 

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthropathy. Five patterns of joint involvement are seen: Arthritis of DIP joint, Asymmetrical oligoarthritis, Symmetrical polyarthritis, Axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joint), and Arthritis mutilans. Nail changes occurs in 90% patients of psoriatic arthritis. Dactylitis, enthesitis and tenosynovitis are also common Shortening of digitis (telescoping), because of underlying osteolysis is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis. Fibrous and bony ankylosis of small joints (greater tendency than RA). Almost any peripheral joint can be involved. Radiological Features includes classical pencil cup deformity of DIP joints.

 

 

Pencil-in-cup deformity

 

Option D. Jaccoud arthropathy. It typically affects MCP joints but can also affect PIP joints of the hand, wrist joint and knee joint. It is a deforming non-erosive arthropathy characterized by ulnar deviation of 2nd-5th fingers with MCP joint subluxation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Involvement of PIP, DIP and 1st CMC with sparing of wrist and MCP is seen in osteoarthritis.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding investigation of malignant bone tumors? (AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. Always done by transverse incision.
  2. Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  3. Sample should be taken before any radiological investigations.
  4. Sample should be taken from periphery and not from necrotic centre.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b and d are correct

 

  • Longitudinal incision is given for bone biopsy.
  • Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  • Radiological investigations are usually done before the biopsy.
  • It is better to take tissue at the periphery of the lesion, where there are viable cells. On the contrary, necrosis and so nondiagnostic tissue are usually present within the tumor. 

 

SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Simple bone cysts are a common pseudotumor of bone and the most frequent cause of pathologic fractures in children.
  • Bone cysts usually affect patients between 5 and 15 years of age and occur more often in boys than in girls (2:1).
  • They are found in the proximal humerus in 50% of cases and in the upper femur in 25%. The calcaneus and pelvis are also uniquely common locations.
  • Patients are asymptomatic until a pathologic fracture occurs.
  • Radiographs typically show a solitary cyst that is centrally located in the metaphyseal area and has marked thinning of the adjacent cortical bone and a pseudoloculated appearance.
  • If there is associated fracture, radiographs may show the characteristic “fallen leaf” sign.
  • In weight-bearing bones, such as the proximal femur, lesions should be treated aggressively.
  • Management:
    • Initial management usually involves aspiration/injection with either bone marrow or corticosteroid.
    • The injections are carried out with bone biopsy needles and are repeated three to five times at intervals of 2 to 3 months, depending on the radiographic response.
    • Curettage and bone grafting may also be an effective modality.

 

OSTEOID OSTEOMA

 

  • The most common benign osteoid-forming tumor is the osteoid osteoma, accounting for 10% of all benign bone tumors.
  • It is more common in males than in females with a peak incidence in the second decade of life.
  • Although it may be present in almost any bone, the proximal femur is the most common location.
  • Dull, aching, nocturnal pain is characteristic, and  it is commonly relieved entirely by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) secondary to a high concentration of prostaglandins in the nidus.
  • Radiographic Feature:
    • Central, lytic nidus usually 1 cm or less in diameter. The more common cortically-based lesion exhibits extensive reactive sclerosis, creating a fusiform bulge on the bone surface. If the nidus is close to, or actually in, a joint, as in a femoral neck lesion, the resulting reactive synovitis may mimic a pyarthrosis or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Technetium bone scans are invariably positive.
    • A CT scan is recommended to better anatomically locate the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
    • In the spine, the typical location for an osteoid osteoma is in the posterior elements.
  • Management:
    • Many cases of osteoid osteoma are stage 1 lesions and can be treated symptomatically with aspirin or NSAIDs until they spontaneously resolve.
    • If the patient fails such treatment, intervention is warranted.
    • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation has emerged as the preferred treatment modality in many cases.
    • If open surgical excision is undertaken, the entire nidus must be eradicated.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10–15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Radiological features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is typically seen in patients in their second or third decade, with a peak in the adolescent growth spurt.
  • Incidence is Males > Females and is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.
    • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic bone may be seen outside the involved bone.
  • Management:
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Longitudinal incision is given for bone biopsy.
  • Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  • Radiological investigations are usually done before the biopsy.
  • It is better to take tissue at the periphery of the lesion, where there are viable cells. On the contrary, necrosis and so nondiagnostic tissue are usually present within the tumor.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented with chronic low back pain. CT scan of the lower back showed the following. Diagnose the condition CT scan image shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spondylolisthesis

 
Spondylolisthesis refers to the slipping or displacement of one vertebra over another. It is commonly caused by a defect or fracture in the pars interarticularis, a part of the vertebra, which leads to instability in the spine. This condition is often visualized as a "slip" on X-rays or CT scans. A characteristic sign is the "beheaded dog" or "Scottish terrier sign," where the neck of the dog (representing the pars interarticularis) appears broken, indicating spondylolysis, which can lead to spondylolisthesis. This vertebral slippage is most commonly observed between the L5 and S1 vertebrae.

 

In this case, the CT scan image shows the typical slip of one vertebra over the other, confirming the diagnosis of spondylolisthesis. This condition often leads to chronic back pain and is frequently associated with nerve compression, particularly at the L5-S1 level.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinal metastasis: This condition involves the spread of cancerous cells to the spine, leading to bone destruction or pathological fractures. However, it does not present with a vertebral slip as seen in this case.

 

Option B. Paget’s disease: Paget’s disease is a disorder of bone remodeling, which leads to abnormally large, misshapen bones. While it can affect the spine, it does not typically present with vertebral slippage.

 

Option C. Renal osteodystrophy: This condition is associated with chronic kidney disease and affects bone density and structure. While it can lead to skeletal deformities, vertebral slippage (spondylolisthesis) is not characteristic of renal osteodystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:


Spondylolisthesis involves the slipping of one vertebra over another, typically visualized in imaging studies. The "beheaded dog" or "Scottish terrier sign" is a key radiographic feature of this condition.

choices.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decreased response to analgesia

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndromes, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly, compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
    • The pain is unrelieved with opioid analgesia.
    • In compartment syndrome, the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: Capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
    • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments.
    • Deep flexor muscles are involved, particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.
    • The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Check radial pulse by displacing the cast. Pulselessness is the late feature to appear in compartment syndrome. It is not a reliable indicator for the presence of the condition.

 

Option C. Change in colour of fingers. This can occur due to vascular insufficiency but is an uncommon entity.

 

Option D. Change in odor. This is not usually observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics. The patient will complaint of no reduction in the pain symptoms.

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations are not used for diagnosing osteoporosis?(INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. DEXA
  2. Bone scan
  3. Quantitative CT
  4. Chemical analysis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) II, IV are correct

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards)
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture.
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A bone scan helps to examine any irregularities in the bone. Sometimes, these bone irregularities may indicate either infection or cancer disease. In addition, it can also help to detect arthritis and bone fractures.

  • Chemical analysis test will not show any diagnostic change because the serum calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels remains normal in osteoporosis. The problem with osteoporosis is of bone quality and not its chemical makeup.

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • DEXA scan is the investigation of choice.
  • Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations.
  • DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.

questions.text: In the fracture seen in the X-ray below, what is the most commonly expected vascular injury?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brachial artery

 

  • The given image shows the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.
  • Fracture supracondylar humerus is:
    • Most common fracture associated with vascular injury.
    • Most common fracture to involve brachial artery (10% cases).
    • Most common cause of volkmann's ischemia and compartment syndrome in children.
    • Most common cause of volkmann's ischemic contracture.
    • Non-union is unknown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radial artery. It can be associated with the fracture of the distal radius.

 

Option C. Ulnar artery. It can be associated with the comminuted fracture of the distal radius.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the supracondylar humerus fracture which is mostly associated with the brachial artery injury.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with long standing history of back pain for 20 years and chest tightness. Lateral radiograph of the cervical spine is shown. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DISH

 

DIFFUSE IDIOPATHIC SKELETAL HYPEROSTOSIS

 

  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a spon­dyloarthropathy also known as Forestier’s disease or ankylosing hyperostosis.
  • It is a noninflammatory disease, with the principal manifestation being calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the entheses.
  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis is characterized by florid hyperostosis of the spine.
  • Marginal bony proliferation leads to the formation of anterior osseous ridges that fuse and give the appearance of flowing wax on the anterior bodies of the vertebrae on radiography.
  • Ossification of paraspinous ligaments, such as the anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments, may be seen.
  • The whole spine may be involved, and bony ankylosis occurs, although the disc spaces and facet joints remain unaffected.
  • The thoracic spine is most commonly involved, although the cervical and lumbar regions may also be affected.
  • Lesions are most prominent anteriorly and along the right lateral aspect of the spine.
  • Intervertebral disc spaces are preserved, unless there is co-existing lumbar spondylosis, and sacroiliac and facet joints appear normal. This helps differentiate diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis from spondylosis and the spondyloarthritis.
  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis is usually seen in the middle-aged and the elderly.
  • In advanced stages, the disease may look like melted candle wax. The calcification and ossification is most common in the right side of the spine.
  • The distinctive radiological feature of DISH is the continuous linear calcification along the anteromedial aspect of the thoracic spine.
  • The disease is not fatal, however some associated complications can lead to death. Complications include paralysis, dysphagia, and pulmonary infections.
  • DISH has no indication of a genetic link, and does not affect organs other than the lungs, which is only indirect due to the fusion of the rib cage.
  • DISH may be discovered as a radiological abnormality, as mentioned above, without any symptoms.
  • Morning stiffness is also noticed in almost two-thirds of patients.
  • Calcification and ossification may be seen at peripheral entheseal sites, including the shoulder, iliac crest, ischial tuberosity, trochanters of the hip, tibial tuberosities, patellae, and bones of the hands and/or feet.
  • Treatment: NSAIDs can be helpful in relieving pain and inflammation associated with DISH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis. Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease. It is a seronegative chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints. HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients. Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis. It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years. Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness for few hours that improves with activity. Question mark (?) posture due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis. Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation. Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation. Spine radiograph shows loss of lumbar lordosis, haziness of SI joint margins (earliest change), calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign), Trolley/Tram-track sign i.e., three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification, Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

 

A. Trolley/Tram track sign; B. Bamboo Spine

 

 

Dagger Sign

 

Option C. Klippel feil syndrome. It is congenital fusion of one or more cervical vertebrae presenting with classical triad of limited neck motion, low hair line and short ‘web' neck (prominent trapezius muscle). Clinical features includes abnormal head position, true torticollis, restricted range of motion, without an obvious SCM contracture, congenital osseous fusions (synostosis) and failure of segmentation of the cervical spine.

 

 

Option D. Sprengel deformity. It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect. The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position. Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue. From the superior angle of scapula, a sheet or band like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae, known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows DISH i.e., diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, which is the non-inflammatory disease, with calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the enthuses, mainly at the thoracic spine.

questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

Educational objective:

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with normal bone mineral density. X-ray is given below. Identify the diagnosis: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

SCURVY

 

  • It is the deficiency of vitamin C, causing defect in the osteoid formation. 
  • The rosary found in this condition is sharp and tender. 
  • Radiological Features: 
    • Sclerosed Margins of Epiphysis
    • Osteopenia – ground glass appearance – 1st sign – thinning of cortex (pencil thin cortex).
    • Metaphysis maybe deformed or fractured.
    • Frankel’s line (zone of provisional calcification increases in width and opacity) due to failure of resorption of calcified cartilage and stands out compared to the severely osteopenic metaphysis.
    • Scurvy line or scorbutic zone (Trummerfeld’s zone) – radiolucent transverse band adjacent to the dense provisional zone.
    • Margins of the epiphysis appears sclerotic, termed as ringing of epiphyses or Wimberger’s sign (Ring sign).
    • Lateral metaphyseal spur (Pelkan spur) at ends of metaphysis is produced by outward projection of zone of provisional calcification and periosteal reaction.
    • Corner or angle sign is peripheral metaphyseal cleft.
    • Subperiosteal hemorrhage in lower end of femur and tibia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickets. In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones. There is irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis, and thin and weak new trabeculae. On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped. The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance); and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

 

 

Option C. Osteopetrosis. Also called as marble bone disease, it is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures, premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Rugger jersey spine is seen. 

 

 

 

Option D. Metaphyseal dysplasia. Also known as Pyle disease, it is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by flaring of the ends of long bones with relative constriction and sclerosis of the diaphysis and mild cranial sclerosis. The flared metaphyses are relatively lucent. The patients are often asymptomatic, although genu valgus deformity may be a feature. Patients present with short-limb dwarfism characterized by coxa vara, and spinal abnormalities. Radiographs reveals bulbous expansion of metaphysis. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image in the question is suggestive of features due to vitamin C deficiency, scurvy. 
  • Following are the features seen in a patient with scurvy on a plain radiograph:

questions.text: A child presented with difficulty in walking. The wrist radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rickets

 

RICKETS

 

  • Osteoid matrix is secreted at normal rate but the mineralization is decreased (i.e. decrease in mineral apposition rate).
  • This leads to increased osteoid maturation time (mineralization).
  • Osteoid is increased in thickness, volume and total surface area.
  • Bone tissue throughout skeleton is incompletely calcified and therefore softened.
  • Rickets refers to condition where it occurs before closure of growth plates so that abnormalities of skeletal growth are superimposed.
  • Pathology:
    • Osteoid is laid down irregularly with widened osteoid seams and osteoid islets may even persist down into the diaphysis.
    • The new trabeculae are thin and weak (as bundle of collagen fibers instead of running parallel to Haversian canal, coarse perpendicularly) and with joint loading, the juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and ‘cup-shaped'.
  • Clinical features:
    • Generalized muscular hypotonia of an unknown mechanism is observed in most patients with clinical (as opposed to biochemical and radiographic) signs of rickets.
    • Craniotabes (areas of thinning and softening of bones of the skull) manifests early in infants with vitamin D deficiency, although this feature may not be present in infants, especially those born prematurely.
    • If rickets occurs at a later age, thickening of the skull develops. This produces frontal bossing and delays the closure of the anterior fontanelle.
    • In the long bones, laying down of uncalcified osteoid at the metaphyses leads to spreading of those areas, producing knobby deformity, which is visualized on radiography as cupping and flaring of the metaphyses.

 

 

  • Weight bearing produces deformities such as bow-legs and knock-knees.
  • In the chest, knobby deformities result in the so-called rachitic rosary along the costochondral junctions. The weakened ribs pulled by muscles also produce flaring over the diaphragm, which is known as Harrison groove. The sternum may be pulled into a pigeon-breast deformity.

 

 

  • In more severe instances in children older than 2 years, vertebral softening leads to kyphoscoliosis. The ends of the long bones demonstrate the same knobby thickening.
  • At the ankle, palpation of the tibial malleolus gives the impression of a double epiphysis (Marfan sign).

 

 

  • Because the softened long bones may bend, they may fracture on one side of the cortex (i.e., greenstick fracture).

 

  • X-rays:
    • Metaphyseal fraying and splaying along with cupping, thickening and widening of growth plate.
    • Bowing of legs and deformities occur at later stages.
  • Investigations:
    • Serum calcium, phosphate, 25-OH vitamin D are reduced.
    • Increased ALP and diminished urinary excretion of calcium.
  • Treatment:
  • Treatment with vitamin D (400-1000 IU per day) and calcium supplements are usually effective.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Osteomalacia. Often referred to as "soft bone disease," is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by the inadequate mineralization of bone tissue. There is adult onset of bone softening and muscle weakness. This condition results from a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, weakening and softening bones. Symptoms are non-specific and may include low back and thigh pain, proximal muscle weakness and wasting; Myalgia and arthralgia; Muscle spasms; waddling gait; Spinal, limb, or pelvic deformities; Aching bone pain aggravated by activity and weight-bearing; Increased falls; Hypocalcemic seizures or tetany. Triradiate pelvis, protrusion acetabular (acetabulum protrudes into pelvis due to bone softening. When bilateral, it is called as Otto Pelvis), pseudofracture are seen on x-ray. There is waddling gait due to muscular weakness.

 

 

A. Triradiate pelvis; B. Protrusio acetabuli

 

Option B. Osteogenesis imperfecta. It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative and qualitative defect in type I collagen formation. There is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen. Most common cause of multiple fractures in childhood. It is inherited from a parent in autosomal dominant (AD) fashion, or may occur as spontaneous mutation, or, rarely as autosomal recessive (AR) trait. The defining clinical feature is osteopenia, causing repeated propensity to fracture, generally after minor trauma and often without much pain or swelling. According to the severity of disease, fractures may occur in uterus, at birth, or after birth prior to or after walking age. Lower limb fractures are more common than upper limb. Femur is commonest bone fractured followed by tibia. Hyperlaxity of ligaments, with resultant hypermobility of joint is common. Blue/gray sclera due to uveal pigment visible through thin collagen layer. Deafness due to otosclerosis/pressure on auditory nerve. Dentinogenesis imperfect/crumbling of teeth i.e., deciduous and permanent teeth break easily and become prone to carries. Lower incisors severely affected. Skin becomes thin and translucent. Muscles are hypotonic due to multiple fractures and deformities. Wormian bones (detached portions of primary ossification centers of adjacent membrane bones) are seen in skull X-ray. Ring-shaped epiphysis is seen. Skeleton: White crumpled-bone shaped not maintained.

 

 

Option D. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity.

 

 

The diagnostic histological feature is irregular area of lamellar bone fitting together like a jigsaw with randomly distributed cement lines. It either occurs in one bone (monostotic) or multiple bones (polyostotic).

 

 

Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. Pain is most common presenting symptom. Limb looks bent and feels thick, and skin is unduly warm due to high vascularity. X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening, coarsening of trabecular markings and lytic and sclerotic changes. Blade of grass lesion is seen.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The image given in the question shows cupping, fraying and splaying of metaphysis of the distal end of both the radius and ulna, which are characteristic of rickets, alongwith walking difficulty.

questions.text: Given below is the X-ray of proximal femur in a patient with pain hip. The deformity shown is:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shepherd crook deformity

 

FIBROUS DYSPLASIA

 

  • Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental anomaly of bone formation.
  • The hallmark is replacement of normal bone and marrow by fibrous tissue and small woven spicules of bone.
  • Fibrous dysplasia can occur in the epiphysis, metaphysis, or diaphysis.
  • It may affect one bone (monostotic form) or several bones (polyostotic form).
  • The monostotic form is the most common and is usually diagnosed in patients between 20 and 30 years of age. It most commonly affects the femur.
  • The polyostotic form typically manifests in children <10 years of age and may progress with age. It most commonly affects the maxilla and other craniofacial bones.
  • McCune-Albright syndrome refers to polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, cutaneous pigmentation (café au lait spots), and endocrine abnormalities (Precoceous puberty).
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called “coast of Maine” borders).
  • Fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur has shepherd crook deformity.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • In long bones, the fibrous dysplastic lesions have ground-glass appearance.

 

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity (looks like shepherds stick which is crooked in shape) bone is replaced by fibrous tissue in fibrous dysplasia.

  • The multiloculated translucent lesion may be surrounded by a sclerotic rim, called ‘Rind sign’.

     

 

A. Shepherd Crook deformity; B. Rind sign 

 

  • Involvement of facial bones may create a leonine appearance (leontiasis ossea).
    • On biopsy, Chinese Letter Pattern is recognised.
    • Surgical treatment (Curettage + bone grafting) is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blade of grass deformity. The blade of grass sign, also called the candle flame sign, refers to the lucent leading edge in a long bone seen during the lytic phase of Paget disease of bone. The lytic, or incipient active, phase of the disease is characterized by intense osteoclastic activity that is exhibited on radiographs as osteolysis. In the long bones, osteolysis is manifested as a characteristic metaphyseal to diaphyseal wedge-shaped area of radiolucency that assumes the configuration of a flame or blade of grass. This advancing wedge of osteolysis, which begins in the subchondral bone of the epiphysis and extends peripherally into the metaphysis and diaphysis, spreads about 1 cm per year and shows no marginal sclerosis. A potential pitfall is misdiagnosing the track sign of the femur as the blade of grass sign.

 

 

Option C. Chicken wire appearance. Histopathologically, cellular areas in chondroblastoma are composed of “chondroblasts” with an oval to round nucleus and with well-defined eosinophilic cytoplasm. A fine network of pericellular calcification called “chicken wire calcification” are seen in the cytoplasm or stroma some cases.

 

 

Option D. Corduroy appearance. Hemangioma is a common benign bone lesion. It is estimated that 10% of the population has asymptomatic hemangioma of the vertebral bodies. Hemangiomas also are common in the skull. They usually are discovered as incidental findings. The radiographic appearance in the spine usually is characteristic, with thickened, vertically oriented trabeculae giving the classic “jailhouse” (Corduroy) appearance. In cross-section, these thickened trabeculae have a “polka dot” pattern on CT scan.

 

Treatment usually is not necessary.

 

 

Polka dot appearance on CT scan

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity is seen in cases of fibrous dysplasia. It is commonly seen deformity with the involvement of femur.

choices.text: Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time.
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day.
Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman with previous history of Colle’s fracture is complaining of backache. Which of the following statement is false?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine. Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss. These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non vertebral fractures.
  • Prolonged used of Bisphosphonates has been reported with increased incidence of fractures of proximal femur. Hence, a patient on Bisphosphonates with hip pain requires X-rays to evaluate and diagnose these fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time. Teriparatide is a recombinant fragment of human parathyroid hormone. To preserve the increments of BMD acquired with teriparatide, therapy with an antiresorptive agent (e.g., bisphosphonates) should restart after teriparatide discontinuation. Bisphosphonates help retain BMD gains that tend to regress after cessation of teriparatide. Concomitant use with teriparatide is to be avoided because they may blunt its anabolic effect.

 

Option C. Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day. 1200 mg of calcium (total of diet and supplement) and 800 international units of vitamin D daily for postmenopausal osteoporosis are recommended.

 

Option D. Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation is a necessary adjunct to all forms of anti-osteoporotic therapies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In post-menopausal osteoporotic females, bisphosphonates can be given for more than a year.
  • But their prolonged use is associated with risk of hip fractures, so it should be assessed with x-rays with time.

questions.text: A patient presents with scoliosis. X-ray shown below. Identify the likely cause:(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital

 

Explanation:

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae.
  • There are four main categories of scoliosis: 
    1. Idiopathic: Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial.
    2. Congenital: Congenital scoliosis accounts for 5-7% of cases and is a result of vertebral abnormalities due to a failure of formation or segmentation of the affected vertebrae.
    3. Neuromuscular (associated with a neurological or muscular disease)
    4. Syndromic (associated with a known syndrome)

 

CONGENITAL SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Congenital scoliosis is the most frequent congenital deformity of the spine.
  • Congenital curvatures are due to anomalous development of the vertebrae (failure of formation and/or segmentation).
  • In most cases, congenital scolioses are non-hereditary.
  • It is believed to be related to an insult to the fetus during spine embryological development (between the 5th-8th week of gestation).
  • 25% of curves are non-progressive, 25% mildly progressive and 50% highly progressive and will require treatment.
  • The mainstay of treatment is either observation or surgery.
  • The rigidity of the curve is assessed, and the rib hump measured.
  • Associated malformations must be looked for clinically: look for foot or leg asymmetry, craniofacial malformation, a Klippel-Feil web neck, and cardiac and urinary malformations.
  • Full-body-width Postero-anterior (PA) and lateral X-rays are essential.
  • After 1 year of age, X-rays should be taken standing, with the legs in extension and the pelvis level, to compensate for any leg length discrepancy.
  • The Cobb angle will be measured.
  • CT scans shows a bony bar.
  • Congenital scoliosis can be classified into defect of formation or defect of segmentation:
    • Fully segmented hemivertebra (two growth plates) with a contralateral bar
    • Unilateral unsegmented bar
    • Two consecutives fully segmented hemivertebrae
    • Fully segmented hemivertebra
    • Semi segmented hemivertebra
    • Wedge vertebra (partial failure of formation)
    • Incarcerated hemivertebra (smaller and induce little deformity as the hemivertebra sits in a non-growing block; the alignment of the pedicles usually remains straight)

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment consists of either observation of the curve or surgery, or, rarely, bracing.
    • Observation should be applied only for non-progressive curves with a balanced spine.
    • Bracing is inefficient in congenital scoliosis. It may be indicated for long flexible curves or to control the compensatory lumbar curve or help rebalancing the spine, or it may be used after an operation, for instance, until the fusion is solid.
    • Surgery is the mainstay of care.
    • Prophylactic surgery:  surgery that will prevent further worsening or allow progressive correction over time. These operations are in situ fusion and hemi epiphysiodesis.
    • In situ fusion can be done with a single posterior fusion, with or without instrumentation or with an anterior fusion, or a 360° fusion.

 

 

  • Hemiepiphysiodesis tends to achieve progressive correction over time, taking advantage of the intact growth plates on the concave side of the deformity.  It has to be done ideally before the age of 5 to take advantage of the growth potential of the spine to allow a progressive correction of the deformity. It should not be carried out if there is a kyphosis component to the deformity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Idiopathic. Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age, but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial. It is grouped by age. In children age 3 and younger, it is called infantile scoliosis. In age 4-10, it is called juvenile scoliosis. In age >10, it is called adolescent scoliosis. Structural curve becomes more prominent on forward bending (Adams test) as opposed to postural scoliosis. Compensatory curve due to limb length discrepancy or sciatic list (due to disc prolapsed) disappear on sitting.  Postural scoliosis disappears on forward bending.

 

Option C. Neuromuscular. This type is caused by a nervous system problem such as cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, spina bifida, and polio. It may present at any age; and in many cases progresses relentlessly, particularly in patients with more severe neurologic and systemic involvement. Progressive deformity may limit mobility and seating status, and may be associated with primary or secondary effects on cardiopulmonary function over time. Management includes observation, non-operative interventions such as bracing, specialized seating systems, and surgery.

 

Option D. Neurofibromatosis. It is hereditary, hamartomatous disorder, that affects central and peripheral nervous system, skeletal, skin and deeper soft tissue. It is one of the commonest single gene disorder affecting the skeletal system. Clinical presentation includes-cafe au lait spots (most common feature) axillary, and inguinal freckling (2nd m.c), cutaneous neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibromas (~5% are premalignant), Lisch nodule on iris, veruccous hyperplasia (thickened overgrown valvety soft skin), elephantiasis (pachy- dermatocele), optic glioma, skeletal abnormalities (scoliosis, congenital pseudoarthrosis of tibia, hemihypertrophy) and cognitive deficits (learning disability).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question shows hemivertebra and block vertebra, which are characteristic of congenital type of scoliosis.

questions.text: Identify the brace given in the following image:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Milwaukee brace

 

  • The brace given in the image is Milwaukee brace that is used for scoliosis.

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae and classified by its anatomic location, in either the thoracic or lumbar spine, with rare involvement of the cervical spine.
  • There are four main categories of scoliosis: 
    1. Idiopathic: Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age, but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial.
    2. Congenital: Congenital scoliosis accounts for 5-7% of cases and is a result of vertebral abnormalities due to a failure of formation or segmentation of the affected vertebrae.
    3. Neuromuscular (associated with a neurological or muscular disease)
    4. Syndromic (associated with a known syndrome)
       
  • Types of scoliosis:

 

 

  • Clinical Findings:
    • Scoliosis in adolescents does not typically cause significant pain. If a patient has significant pain, she/he should be evaluated to rule out the possibility of some other disorder such as infection or tumor.
    • Deformity of the rib cage and asymmetry of the waistline are clinically evident for curvatures of 30 degrees or more.
    • Lesser curves may be detected through a forward bending test (Adam’s test), which is designed to detect early abnormalities of rotation that may not be apparent when the patient is standing erect.
    • Rotation of the spine may be measured with a scoliometer. Rotation is associated with a marked rib hump as the lateral curvature increases in severity.
       
  • Imaging:
    • Radiographs taken of the entire spine in the standing position in both the posterior anterior (PA) and lateral planes are the most valuable for diagnosis.
    • Usually, a primary curve is evident with compensatory curvature to balance the body.
    • Skeletal maturity can be assessed by the Risser sign. A radiograph is employed to see how far the patient's iliac apophysis has progressed from the anterior superior iliac spine. During development, the iliac apophysis first appears laterally and grows medially. The stages are Risser I-V, where Risser V denotes that the apophysis has completely fused with the iliac crest and therefore, skeletal maturity can be assumed hence, further progression of curve of scoliosis will not take place.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of scoliosis depends on the curve magnitude, skeletal maturity, and risk of progression.
    • Specific management is dependent on the Cobb angle, measured on a standing PA X-ray of the spine.
    • Brace treatment is restricted to immature children in an attempt to prevent curve progression during further skeletal growth. So, it is indicated in Growing adolescents (Risser 0, 1 or 2) who, on presentation, have curves in range of 30-45 degrees or who have had documented progression exceeding 5 degrees in curve that initially measured 20-30 degrees.
    • TLSOs are the most commonly used orthoses today, but their use is restricted to patients whose curve apex is at or below T7.
    • Suspensory plaster cast of sayre, Rissers cast hinge or turnbuckle cast of Hibbs and Kisser, Milwaukee brace, Boston brace, Charleston night-time bending brace, Wilmington brace and thoraco-lumbo- sacral orthoses (TLSOs) are used to treat idiopathic scoliosis (Lower Dorsal scoliosis > Lumbar Scoliosis).
    • Surgical treatment consists of corrective osteotomies and fusion.
    • Spinal instrumentation (rods,  screws, hooks, etc.) are applied to the region of the spine to be corrected through transpedicular route and bone graft is added.
    • Spinal fusions are delayed as long as possible in young children through the use of casting, bracing, and growth modulating surgeries such as growing rods or vertical expandable prosthetic titanium ribs (VEPTR).

 

 

  • Milwaukee Brace: 
    • The Milwaukee brace is an active corrective spinal orthosis.
    • It consists of a neck ring with a throat mould and two occipital pads to avoid a high pressure in the neck.
    • Other elements are a plastic pelvic girdle, aluminium uprights, leather L-shaped thoracic pads and metal bars in the front and in the back.
    • It is used in the treatment of postural disorders like idiopathic scoliosis or Scheuerman disease.
    • The brace is normally prescribed for children, with a postural disorder, who have not reached their growth spurt or who are in their fast growing period.
    • It is not used for adults or adolescents already beyond their growth spurt, as it will have no effect.
    • If the spinal curve has a Cobb angle between 20° and 40°, it is an indication to use a brace.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The brace shown in the image in the question is of a Milwaukee brace, which is used to treat scoliosis in adolescent children.

questions.text: Bone mineral density screening is recommended after the age of:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 65 years

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards).
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts

 

 

Codfish Vertebrae

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bone mineral density screening by DEXA scan is recommended at the age more than 65 years.

questions.text:
Assertion: Decompression surgery is needed with progressive neurological difficulty in Pott’s spine. (AIIMS May 2019)

 

Reason: Even after completion of ATT, there can be neurological abnormalities.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion

 

  • When there is stage 4 of pott’s spine with bladder/bowel involvement and more than 50% of sensory loss, the treatment of choice is decompression surgery with bone graft, along with continuation of ATT.
  • Even after the completion of ATT, there can be presence of neurological abnormalities.

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • The spine is the most common site of skeletal tuberculosis, accounting for 50% of cases followed by hip (15%) and knee (10%).
  • Any level of the spine may be involved, the lower thoracic region being the most common followed by lumbar > upper dorsal > cervical > sacral region.
  • Types:

 

 

  • Clinical features: Pain, stiffness, cold abscess formation, paraplegia, deformity, fever, weight loss.
  • Imaging:
    1. Plain radiograph:
      • Reduction of disc space
      • Vertebral body destruction
      • Paravertebral abscess
      • Widening of mediastinum
    2. CT scan: 
      • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.
    3. MRI: 
      • It is the investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
      • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.
    4. Biopsy: 
      • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.
  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:
    • Stage 1: Patient has no neural complaint clinician elicits increased reflexes.
    • Stage 2: Patient has weakness but can walk with support.
    • Stage 3: Patient is non-ambulatory or has sensory loss <50%.
    • Stage 4: Patient has bowel/bladder involvement or sensory loss >50%.
  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India.
    • Patient is treated by antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on nonoperative management but if indications of surgery exist  then he needs to be operated.
  • Stage-wise Treatment:

 

 

  • ATT: 
    • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
    • Minimum duration is 9-12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18-24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB, the duration of ATT is 6 months-1 year).
  • Indications of surgery in any disease of spine:
    1. Bowel bladder involvement.
    2. Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
    3. No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks or
    4. Surgical options for most of the cases are: anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
    5. Hong Kong operation is also carried out for Pott’s spine.
    6. Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed).

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

Note:

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.

 

Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When there is stage 4 of pott’s spine with bladder/bowel involvement and more than 50% of sensory loss, the treatment of choice is decompression surgery with bone graft, along with continuation of ATT.
  • Even after the completion of ATT, there can be presence of neurological abnormalities.

questions.text: Match the following named fractures with the bones involved:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-c

 

 

COMMON FRACTURE EPONYMS

 

 

1. March fracture:

  • Fatigue/stress fracture of the neck of 2nd and 3rd metatarsals.
  • More common in neck of 2nd metatarsal than 3rd metatarsal.

 

 

2. Bennett’s fracture:

  • Intra-articular fracture dislocation of base of 1st metacarpal.
  • Shaft is laterally dislocated by the unopposed pull of the abductor pollicis longus.
  • The medial projection of the thumb metacarpal base on which the volar oblique ligament attaches, remains in place.

 

 

3. Jones fracture:

  • Avulsion fracture at the base of 5th metatarsal at the metaphysio-diaphyseal junction.

 

 

4. Boxer’s fracture:

  • Fracture through the neck of 5th metacarpal.
  • More common in boxers.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male after a fall in bathroom had hip fracture as seen in the pelvic X-ray below. What will be the position of the left lower limb?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shortened and externally rotated

 

HIP FRACTURE

 

  • The given image in the question shows a displaced femoral neck fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly.
  • In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as fall from a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. 
  • Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density.
  • 70% of all hip fractures occur in women. 
  • Symptoms include pain in the groin or pain referred along the medial side of the thigh and knee in an impacted fracture.
  • In a displaced fracture, there will be pain in the entire hip. 
  • In an impacted fracture, there is no obvious clinical deformity on examination. There is mild discomfort in the active/passive hip range of motion, and pain with percussion over the greater trochanter.
  • In displaced fractures, the leg appears in external rotation and abduction deformity with shortening of the limb.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows a displaced femoral neck fracture in the elderly patient.
  • Following the fracture, the limb appears shortened with external rotation and abduction deformity at the hip.
